title: 10 Things I Hate About You
rewatchability: 1h30, not too memorable, but funny
review: Pretty solid popcorn flick. There are some decent laughs here, and characters like Kat (Julia Stiles) are pretty iconic, so that’s good. Cameron (Joseph Gordon-Levitt) is the most consistently likable character, but Patrick is cool enough to give him the win here. Most of the other characters are pretty annoying (high school movie, so not really surprising) and the plot does complicate itself a little too much, but the 90s comedy is still more entertaining than most of what is put out today. Pretty cookie-cutter plot, to the point where I could probably have guessed the entire script in broad strokes just from the IMDb synopsis, but the individual moments work together to make it stand out from all the other 90s high-school rom-coms out there. Speech at the end is not bad, I guess, and the massive song is setting the bar way too high for promposals. Also I find it weird how Bianca (Larisa Oleynik) just kisses Cameron and he stops thinking she’s awful, but whatever works, I guess.

title: 21 Jump Street
rewatchability: Once a month if you want, it’s not really that deep
review: Funny bro-cop movie with heart. Jonah Hill and Channing Tatum have pretty good chemistry, and their characters are pretty naturally funny, so it’s definitely just a good funny movie to watch. The hallucination scenes had me proper laughing, and the supporting cast is cool too. Ice Cube, Rob Riggle, and Dakota Johnson (obviously super good looking) are good comedic sides, but Brie Larson was the most impressive actor here. After all the bad press she’s been getting (after Captain Marvel) it was good to see that she’s actually charming and a great actor. Anyway, the way the movie made fun of most of the modern school stereotypes is cool, and overall it’s a good all-nighter popcorn flick.

title: 22 Jump Street
rewatchability: Once a month if you want, it’s not really that deep
review: They pretty much made as many connections to the original themselves, so that doesn’t leave much to go over. They switched out Brie Larson for Amber Stevens West and gave Ice Cube a bigger part this time around. Dave Franco’s cameo was hilarious, and ofc the chemistry between the leads was still the thing that made the movie. I did see this like a month before going to college, so I was totally scarred by the experience, even after considering that it was Hollywood college. So thanks for re-condemning frats in my eyes, movie. Still, it’s funny, and the lambo gag was fun. The football plotline wasn’t really too funny for me though.

rewatchability: 2h, great acting
review: I don’t even like baseball, but man, Chadwick Boseman is THE man. The dignity with which he plays Robinson (who I really respect now, too) is what makes this movie. The “underdog” story of fighting racism in sport progresses terribly fluently with a likable protagonist and a charismatic supporting cast of Mr. Rickey (Harrison Ford), Rachel Robinson (Nicole Beharie), and Wendell (Andre Holland), alongside the many entertaining Dodgers teammates. Music is great, costumes and direction, and even the accents compliment the overall reality of the scenes and the threats that Jackie faced. Pee-Wee (Lucas Black) said it best, “Maybe one day we’ll all wear 42.” They do now.

title: 5 Centimeters per Second
rewatchability: It’s really serious, and more of a one-time experience
review: I’m pretty sure Makoto Shinkai is my favorite director. Everything he does just ends me. And even though this movie (if you want to call it that - it’s really three chapters) is formally listed as a “romance drama”, I really think it’s more realistic than most of the romance movies I’ve seen. I mean this straight up broke my heart, “500 days of summer” style. I’m relatively naive, so I haven’t completely given up on love (like Takaki), so pretty much everything he does hits REALLY hard. His relationship with Akari (Yoshimi Kondou) from the time they’re kids to adults is the focus of the movie, and that’s really all you need to know. It’s visually beautiful (as usual) and the visual storytelling is wonderful for both insightful and casual viewers. My only issue was that it’s plot didn’t have too many events, and maybe a longer runtime might have helped with that. But for what it is, it’ll definitely give you something to think about. Warning though, it might break your heart.
spoilerReview: That end scene. WHY DOES SHINKAI KEEP DOING THIS? Killed my heart to see that there was no one behind that train. But I guess that’s what the movie was about - relationships fade. Love fades, if you allow it to. Killed me. Takaki being emotionally unavailable around Kanae also hit home. And knowing that Akari got married without Takaki even knowing… my heart hurts even now. Love is hard, man. So yeah, Shinkai does it again. I don’t really know why they spent all that time focusing on Kanae’s family and sister and stuff, but there must be some reason. Also apparently the falling cherry blossom petals are a metaphor for relationships growing apart with time? Mad. I really liked the callback though, it was cute.

title: A Few Good Men
rewatchability: Once a month if you want
review: Apparently Tom Cruise made lots of adrenaline movies in the 90s. Maybe a movie about lawyers doesn’t sound too exciting, but Colonel Jessup (Jack Nicholson) is always a scary villain, and Cruise is awesome as a witty lead. Demi Moore’s Lt. Galloway has great chemistry with Cruise, and is a strong female character, and Kevin Bacon and Keifer Sutherland are a good supporting cast. Music is pretty good too.
spoilerReview: Of course, this movie is HELLA quotable, particularly the end court scene - “YOU CANT HANDLE THE TRUTH” and “You’re under arrest you son of a bitch.” Mega boss moves.

title: A Silent Voice
rewatchability: It’s 2h, and quite emotional
review: The number of times I yelled at the screen… this movie is OUTRAGEOUS. There’s tugging at the heartstrings, and then there’s ripping them out. Violently. Take a guess which one this movie chooses. There’s so much tragedy in each character’s mind that you don’t know who to hate and when (lesson: kids suck). The director, Naoko Yamada, does a great job with motifs and visual storytelling for Ishida’s (Miyu Iruno) character. His relationship with the other characters in school, mainly the deaf Nishimiya, is the main plot of this movie. But it is TRAGIC. Not in the Julius Caesar way, but in a really psychologically probing way. The animation is great, the voice acting is wonderful (especially for the Winner) and the plot is something that no one should miss out on. The entire ensemble of characters, Yuzuru (Ao Yuki), Ueno (Yuki Kaneko), Nagatsuka (Kensho Ono), Kawai (Megumi Han), and Sahara (Yui Ishikawa) all represent distinct types of people with real flaws, making the movie hit home to that many more people. The parents, especially Nishimiya’s mom (Akiko Hiramatsu) and Ishida’s mom (Satsuki Yurino) have such devastating reactions to the events in the movie as well. Definitely important to watch, if you’re prepared to understand many complex characters. And if you’re like me, you’ll definitely appreciate the messages about the unseen struggles that deaf people endure - I’m going to try and learn ASL as soon as possible.
spoilerReview: The first 20 minutes of the movie? I was absolutely ready to SHOOT THOSE KIDS. I’m not a fan of kids as it is, but when Nishimiya’s ears started bleeding, I was going to throw hands. It took me almost the whole movie to forgive Ishida. But kids are going to be horrible, right? So it made sense. And that’s why I was that much angrier at Ueno when she started messing with Nishimiya when they were older. And Kawai’s random outbursts? Loathing. The number of suicide attempts in this movie, too… it’s definitely an important thing to recognize the reactions of the family and friends. So yeah, not the most rewatchable movie, not the most consistently comfortable, but it’s powerful and has a great message.

title: A Star is Born
intendedAudience: People who like musicals, realistic dramas, and mature romance movies
rewatchability: It’s 2h15, and LONG, but the songs definitely keep it fresh
review: I feel like this movie was just a great opportunity for everyone to show off their skills. Lady Gaga was awesome at flexing her voice, as well as her emotional acting, and Bradley Cooper as Jackson Maine was definitely a really cool deuteragonist. They had great chemistry, and Cooper’s directing was really complimentary to stressing the emotional instability of both of the main characters. Bobby (Sam Elliot) was definitely a good emotional backup to Jackson’s story, Ramon (Anthony Ramos) was funny, and Rez (Rafi Gavron) played a vital role in delving into the effects of going into showbusiness and the kind of people who have influence over artists’ creativity. Shallow is the highlight, of course, just an absolute great song, and I’m glad that they used it so well in the movie. The intimacy between Ally and Jackson was really unique and personal, and Jackson’s drinking issues were definitely a factor in everything that happened. The ending wasn’t bad, but they did manage to capitalize on the opportunity to be idealistic with the quotes.

title: Ae Dil Hai Mushkil
intendedAudience: Hindi movie fans, romance drama fans
rewatchability: 2h30, so definitely only like once in a couple years
review: I don’t know what it is about unrequited love that makes for just the most dramatic stories, but it seems to be working its magic here as well. Ayan (Ranbir Kapoor) is actually a really relatable hero in the sense that he’s really vulnerable, and his chemistry with Alizeh (Anushka Kapoor) was so strong in the first half of the movie that I couldn’t help but feel a strong attraction to her myself. Saba (Aishwarya Rai) and Ali (Fawad Khan) were the supporting cast, and I thought Rai did a pretty great job, but Shah Rukh Khan’s one-scene cameo absolutely stole the show, his lines completely summing up what the movie was about. The dialogue is actually great for the most part, particularly the banter between the characters and the poetry-type scenes. Obviously, music was great, especially the wedding scene. Theme-wise this movie was also really mature, and I was glad that it didn’t have any gimmicky elements that were a staple of this genre. Definitely a solid effort all around.

title: Alien
rewatchability: Probably wouldn’t
review: Yeah, I don’t even know. It took me 3 days to watch this, which is crazy, since I can actually watch 3 movies a day. But yeah, it’s got suspense. And aliens. And blood. The pacing is weird, the characters (with the exception of Ripley) are forgettable, the lighting is awful (like really dark, I swear I couldn’t see anything), and the plot is really slow. Sure, there was a lot of set detail for 1979, but the story wasn’t much more than “there are aliens”. Still, the end scene got a reference in Avengers Infinity War, and there were a few dramatic scenes here and there, so I’ll give it a pass.

title: Angels and Demons
intendedAudience: Not kids, maybe not super conservative Christians
rewatchability: Once a year, max
review: Dan Brown is such a beast that I feel guilty rating these movies, because they’re just so impressive. The elements that he incorporates from history and religion are recognizable to the layman and are iconic references to those who are familiar with them. Not only the plot, but the characters in this movie are also quite fleshed out. Robert Langdon (Tom Hanks), Vittoria Vetra (Ayelet Zurer), Commander Richter (Stellan Skarsgard), and the Camerlengo were all main character material, with compelling moments and characteristics that made them all relevant to the plot. Even the Assassin’s (Nikolaj Lie Kaas) character was shockingly honourable. The music and pacing used to hold the audience in and create suspense are probably the best aspects of these movies, and you’ll definitely learn something that you didn’t know before.
spoilerReview: Not exactly sure how they collected antimatter, but sure. The whole elemental part of the mystery, with Earth, Air, Fire, and Water, was really cool to watch, especially when he was looking for historical connections to each. The map drawing to show symmetry and the initial message deciphering was really cool. Also the Camerlengo burning himself was so metal; the whole business with the helicopter was pretty cool too. The Assassin’s scenes were quite entertaining also.

title: Arrival
intendedAudience: People who like sci-fi movies and Nolan-type films
rewatchability: 2h, pretty interesting plot
review: So in terms of subject matter, this movie is definitely really awesome. Just the colours when Louise and Ian (Jeremy Renner) interact with the heptapods, with the camera angles and the tension in the score are awesome, and I liked the design of the aliens. Their language was probably the star of this movie, as was the characters’ conversation of language’s connection to cognition and how we as a species think because of how we communicate. Watching Louise teach the aliens and learn their language was really cool to watch as time went on, and the world powers’ reaction to the situation looked pretty reasonable (unfortunately for us in the real world). Still, the ending moral of the movie was strong and had a sense of promise, even with some possible tragedy that needs to be embraced. Colonel Weber (Forest Whitaker) was surprisingly supportive, even if I felt Ian didn’t really do that much.
spoilerReview: So the “offer weapon” thing was a really cool scene, and her figuring out it was actually a gift, and that she could look into the future, was really nice. The way they showed her using this power to influence what’s going on, especially with General Sang (Tzi Ma), was cool. And then the big reveal of her daughter actually being in the future and dying from an incurable disease, but her still choosing to go through with it was definitely something, although I didn’t care too much about the daughter. It was pretty sad watching the world stop talking to each other, and quite annoying when the podcasters were criticizing everything for no reason, but it was accurate.

title: Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery
rewatchability: Might get on your nerves if you keep watching consistently
review: This movie is a meme, by all means, and is so frustrating to sit through, but it IS funny. Full credit to Mike Myers for playing both Austin Powers and Dr. Evil (I seriously didn’t catch this, somehow). They make fun of all the spy movie cliches, which is where Vanessa (Elizabeth Hurley) comes in, and she’s also fairly good in this role. Everything is really, really over-the-top, but I don’t think it ever gets too slow, particularly on first viewing. The storyline with the son is pretty random, as are the female robots and the transitions with the band, and Austin’s teeth are just not nice to look at. Lots of randomness.

title: Avengers: Endgame
intendedAudience: MCU fans and anyone vaguely connected to them (basically everyone not living under a rock)
rewatchability: Once a year
review: If you need to wrap up a saga of twenty-two interconnected movies spanning decades and galaxies, it’s hard to do it much better than the Russo brothers did with Endgame. With all the OG Avengers at center stage, all the favorites had a healthy amount of screentime with decent to excellent resolutions/continuations of their character arcs. Score was decent (can’t go wrong with Silvestri), even if it didn’t seem to match up to Infinity War’s. Pacing felt kind of inconsistent, but there’s a lot going on, so it’s forgivable to have rushed in places. Though there are some really powerful shots, overall the visuals weren’t quite as stunning as Infinity War’s. The cinematography felt average, and the color palette was more muted for no particularly good reason, especially during the third act, which could not have chosen a more boring place to happen. Humor was on point, and this movie brought in ALL THE FEELS. Ton of fan service, which is to be expected. Thanos is a far less interesting villain than in his last outing, and his power scaling is a little messed up, but he remains as intimidating as ever. Very rewarding watch, even if those without prior MCU knowledge will be a bit lost. The greatest danger here is overwatching, since Endgame is meant as the culmination of everything that came before it, so it doesn’t work as well without that emotional setup.

title: Baby Driver
rewatchability: Action, 2h, I’d say once in a couple months
review: Edgar Wright has some die-hard fans, and even though I’m not a savant, I definitely think his method of direction is fabulous in this movie. The biggest thing is the MUSIC. This movie is basically just all bangers. There was one bit that looked like a music lyrics video, but still somehow fit into the scene wonderfully. Wonderful. Made use of Baby’s ear trauma masterfully. Then there’s Debora (Lily James), who’s basically cinderella, and pairs really well with Ansel. The supporting cast of John Hamm, Eiza Gonzalez (who are great looking and I can’t believe she has 3 z’s in her name), Jamie Foxx, and Kevin Spacey, all pull their weight and make the movie engaging from start to finish. The pacing is pretty good, there’s some good comedy, a few glimpses of heart, and really really good action. That’s the selling point, and it definitely delivers.
spoilerReview: Is it just me, or is Kevin Spacey just meant to be the villain? I totally expected him to be the villain. Anyway, I felt like the step-dad knowing USL was an interesting touch, and it was cool how Baby handled the ending with him. There were quite a lot of endings, and even though they were all pretty satisfying, they didn’t all make sense. Debora waiting five years, the police not arresting Debora with Baby, etc. Still, the ending was cool, and Lily James is awesome, so we’ll let it slide.

title: Ballerina
rewatchability: Maybe once a year is possible
review: Super underrated. Didn’t even know about this movie until my roommate recommended it to me, and I’m so glad that he did. The relationship between Felicie (Elle Fanning) and Victor (Dane DeHaan) is honestly one of the most charming animated movie kid pairings, and watching them contend against the world is really inspiring. I felt like Odette’s kindness and calm, motherly personality was just spectacular in contrast to the kids, and they fit extremely well together - so glad that she got her respect at the end. Camille LeHaut (Maddie Ziegler) and Rudolph (Tamir Kepallan) kept the narrative interesting too, even if the Mrs. LeHaut (Kate McKinnon) was totally cartoonishly crazy. Luteau (Mel Brooks) was also really heartwarming at the end - shows the power of a good dream. Movie is also called LEAP! But I think the international release is Ballerina, and I think this movie’s charm is its European influence, so that’s what I’ve chosen.

title: Beauty and the Beast
rewatchability: It’s a little slow at times, and 2h, so maybe only a couple times ever
review: Okay, I can’t think of a way to describe this that’s not “Not bad”. I’ve been an Emma Watson fan for a while (like most other fantasy-loving kids) and it’s good to see that she does a good job acting in this movie. Unfortunately, there really isn’t much for her to do in this role (or in most roles in this movie, honestly). Everyone was par, is what I feel like. The beast (Dan Stevens) was a pretty cool character, but the supporting cast really stole the show, especially Lumiere and Cogsworth (Ian McKellen), who have hilarious banter, and LeFou (Josh Gad), who’s great comic relief. Gaston (Luke Evans) is really just the worst, and I didn’t really feel the movie’s heart too much, unfortunately. It’s cool that she likes books, though. And the songs and outfits and nice.

title: Bee Movie
rewatchability: Meme, so constantly
review: So the thing is, this movie is weird, but it’s funny. Barry (Jerry Seinfeld) is just such a bee version of Seinfeld, and his humour was just great for me. Seinfeld writes and delivers really well here too. Then Adam is Matthew Broderick, which is an instant bonus (I’m a bit of a superfan). Still, Barry’s relationship with Vanessa is just so absurdly funny to watch, and it’s arguably even funnier to watch the other characters react in outrage to the two of them - particularly Ken (Patrick Warburton). There’s so many little pop-culture inserts with Chris Rock as a mosquito, Larry King as himself, Ray Liotta as himself, etc. But the message of the movie is actually still decently meaningful in that it expresses the importance of bees’ existence to our ecosystems. They do slip in a bunch of pretty interesting bee facts too.

title: Before Sunrise
rewatchability: Probably once ever
review: Vienna is really nice. Super commercial for it. Also, this movie is basically 1h45 of two people talking, and it’s entirely carried by the chemistry between Jesse and Celine (Julie Delpy). It’s really cute, basically. It’s a date movie. The premise is some kind of meet-cute and a one-off wonderful night between two people. There isn’t really anything groundbreaking, but it’s just two attractive actors talking for a couple hours. Cinematography, dialogue is all great - it actually looks like they might have improvised many of the conversations, because they were really really casual and automatic.

title: Black Panther
intendedAudience: There’s some violence, so pretty much everyone above like 5
rewatchability: Didn’t seem too long, even at 2h 15m
review: There’s nothing like a good superhero movie villain, and Killmonger’s foil-like nature when compared to T'Challa made him perfect as the antagonist. That, and his stylish yet intense arrogance, coupled with a great character story, created one of the best superhero movie villains of yet. The rest of the cast did great as well (Chadwick Boseman, Letitia Wright, Danai Gurira, Martin Freeman, Andy Serkis, Forest Whitaker, Winston Duke, Angela Bassett, Lupita Nyong’o), with both Shuri and Okoye balancing amusing and endearing moments with T’Challa, with more dramatic instances. The soundtrack and the direction was exemplary, building into the urban/rural mystical world that they’ve built in Wakanda.
spoilerReview: Despite the obvious nature of T’Challa’s return, its execution was conducted fairly well, giving M’Baku some character as well as giving T’Challa’s mother more depth. Bucky’s exclusion was probably a good idea, since the film focused on entirely new characters. Killmonger’s death and final scene with T’Challa was probably one of the best in the movie, showcasing both Jordan and Boseman’s acting abilities.

title: Black Swan
rewatchability: Never
review: I swear to god I wasn’t expecting this movie to be so damn scary. Well it was. Straight up, I watched it in the night thinking it was some ballet movie and I had the shock of my life. This is the scariest shit I’ve seen to date, and best believe I’m not watching it again. Of course, there’s a lot of imagery with Nina and Lily and the White and Black Swans, and the whole play is fine. But between Nina’s being crazy and her mom being the weirdest person to live EVER, this movie makes me feel SO UNCOMFORTABLE. But if you like horror and being creeped out and the ballet, then I’m betting you’re going to love this.

title: Black Widow
rewatchability: It’s 2h15, action and comedy, but not mindblowing
review: I feel like my expectations for this movie were just too high - I have been a bit starved of movie trips recently. I kept waiting for the third act to start, but the movie kinda just ended, so I felt a little unsatisfied. I don’t remember anything wrong about the movie per se, maybe the pacing, but Natasha (Scarlett Johansson) is cool as always and Yelena is an awesome new addition to the MCU. I like the familial dynamic between the girls, Melina (Rachel Weisz) and Alexei (David Harbour). Supporting cast of Ross (William Hurt) and Valentina (Julia Louis-Dreyfus). The plug Agent (O. T. Fagbenle) was funny, but the villains were a little meh. Taskmaster’s concept was cool, but I felt they misused Olga Kurylenko and misplayed the emotional stakes with the whole Budapest callback. Dreykov (Ray Winstone) was interesting, but his menacingness did evaporate way too quickly. The action itself was pretty good though, even if it’s difficult to believe they survive so many explosions and car crashes. Also this movie is almost entirely women, and it worked so well that nobody really noticed or made a big noise about it. People were comparing it to Captain Marvel, and this movie isn’t perfect, but it’s less forced, and its focus is rightly on Natasha and her bond with family.
spoilerReview: The starting was definitely awesome, and it was great to see young Natasha and Yelena together with their fake parents. Their young actresses (Ever Gabo Anderson and Violet McGraw respectively) did really well too. My favourite part of the movie was probably the montage with a slow acapella Smells Like Teen Spirit (by Malia J, original by Nirvana). Really really dark scenes, but they were really hard-hitting. Definitely great backstory to Natasha’s character that we’ve only heard of. I found Dreykov’s whole pheromone thing really stupid, and Natasha’s severed nerve thing was arguably even worse - him dying fell pretty flat too. The scene at the end where she looks into the distance as Ross and his cars show up really confused me, since they were just trying to arrest her earlier, and she ends up totally fine. So that was a little wack. I also really wanted Captain America to show up at the end, so that was sad.

title: Blade Runner
rewatchability: Probably have to watch it twice to understand
review: So this movie also doesn’t exactly have the right branding for new-comers. I thought this would be a normal dystopian thriller with a charismatic lead in Rick Deckard (Harrison Ford). But it’s really more in line with ethical, speculative science-fiction that isn’t as popular as you’d think. The movie is based around human-like androids called ‘replicants’ having escaped some prison/factory and Rick having to kill them (he’s a space policeman, which they call Blade Runner). So the message here is asking the audience what really differentiates the replicants from humans, if anything - especially given the characters’ vast repulsion with replicants. Roy, Pris (Daryl Hannah), and Rachael (Sean Young) all give great performances, and the end scene from Roy is easily the best and most pronounced scene in the movie. Pacing is pretty slow, and you really have to stick in there to last to the last 20 minutes (the good bit).
spoilerReview: So the big question is: Is Rick a replicant? Definitely the right way to go with the movie, and the only way to make this premise interesting. The unicorn motif - I honestly missed this - was a good storytelling device, and the rain speech at the end was wonderful. I just wished they wasted less time. Also Roy’s acting was great, but he kept doing really weird things for no reason (especially in the third act). The conversation between him and Tyrell (Joe Turkel) was good though.

title: Blade Runner 2049
rewatchability: Depends on preference
review: I’ll just say it—whoever thought it was a good idea to put Denis Villeneuve in charge of a Blade Runner movie was absolutely cooking with gas. 2049 takes the questions and themes put forward in the original and makes them feel fresh and—ironically, given the setting and protagonist—human in a way they couldn’t quite manage to be in the original. Visually it’s obviously a huge step up from 1982, and Hans Zimmer is about as close as you can get to a spiritual successor for Vangelis’s iconic score. K (Ryan Gosling) shows a ridiculous amount of subtlety in his performance given how stoic his character is supposed to be outwardly, and his holographic girlfriend Joi (Ana de Armas) was both an interesting concept and enjoyable to watch. Some scenes run a little long probably—Villeneuve’s Achilles heel seems to be that he’s a little too fond of chewing up the scenery longer than he really needs to—which makes the pacing a little weird in the middle.

title: Bohemian Rhapsody
rewatchability: Just for the songs, you could rewatch daily
review: Weeeee are the Champions, my friends. Freddie Mercury is Freddie Mercury, and there will never be another, but Rami Malek does a wonderful job capturing his enigmatic, charismatic personality. The Queen members Roger (Ben Hardy), John (Joseph Mazello), Brian (Gwilym Lee) and Mary-Austin (Lucy Boynton) were an amazing supporting cast, and Paul (Allen Leech) was utilized wonderfully in the narrative. But the SONGS. Guys, the songs. Sure, the backstory with Freddie’s parents is great for general knowledge and serves as a heartwarming ending, but LIVE AID. Watch till the end, is all I can say.

title: Booksmart
intendedAudience: Solo works, but probably stick to friends so you can laugh out loud without feeling like a loser
rewatchability: A year, give or take
review:
The movie lets you know right away that it’s not afraid to make you uncomfortable. It  was sorta dialing everything up to eleven, but a couple other moments also were a little too real, which really shouldn’t work but it really really does. Absolutely HILARIOUS, couple of characters are straight up iconic, and a couple of scenes had me almost laughing aloud on the plane. What made the movie for me was that everything, no matter how weird, always tied into the protagonists and their friendship (chemistry was ON POINT). Balances the humor and super emotional character moments really well, and the soundtrack definitely helped with that (standout: Slip Away by Perfume Genius).

Spoilers: GIGI. Give this woman her own movie. Also, the Cardi B and not-really-cocaine moments were iconic. The hookup scene was def an L, but also pretty funny, so that works ig. Felt really bad for the panda, and Lisa Kudrow being Lisa Kudrow was great. I guess the kid with the car (idr his name) was kinda annoying, and Hope was forgettable ish (her relationship w/ Amy was not set up AT ALL, and she had no character except for being a sarcastic girl who’s actually nice on the inside. Wanted to like her, but nooooo.) The movie’s about the friendship though, not the love interests, so I’m okay with it.

title: Borat Subsequent Moviefilm
rewatchability: This one’s super specific to 2020, and works best as a one-off
review: Okay, so I was wrong - someone CAN beat Sacha Baron Cohen apparently. Watching this in 2020 is likely the only option here, and I feel like it manages to convey its political point fairly well without any direct exposition. It’s still weird as hell, and apparently these movies do shoot without scripted extras, so MASSIVE respect to them for being camera-worthy. My main issue with this is that I don’t know whether this is fiction or reality, which worries me a LOT. Otherwise, Tutar as a kid was hilarious, and she’s got a lot of heart that was a nice change-up from the first movie (although this one does borrow a LOT of elements from that one). And it goes without saying that it’s definitely a meme, because if it wasn’t, I don’t really know what I’d do with myself.
spoilerReview: Big respect for the movie for actually crashing a Trump rally (with footage of Pence) and managing to get a real Rudy Guilliani interview. The whole COVID-19 plot was pretty funny in the end too. Once again, the religious scenes were the funniest (the church scene from the first one and the synagogue scene from this one) and there was a lot of heart from the women extras. I feel like the abortion scene was pretty funny too, since it was objectively a misunderstanding between the pastor and both of them.

title: Borat: Cultural Learnings Of America For Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan
rewatchability: Either never or every week
review: Okay, I think it’s impossible for Sacha Baron Cohen not to win in a movie that he stars in. That’s just how it works. But after watching, I can confidently say that I hope this never shows up on TV. Don’t get me wrong, it was obviously entertaining, and it definitely got more than a few laughs out of me, but a fair number of cringes as well. I decided to play it safe and slap it in the Meme, since I’m pretty confident that I’m not rewatching it, and Existent doesn’t do it justice. So yeah, definitely an experience. It’s like the Office meets Deadpool meets the Dictator. I don’t even think an R rating is enough. That said, movie-wise it’s got all the artistic chops - dialogue was memorable (“Ma name Borat”), shooting style was unique, and the plot was definitely something to behold. So yeah, entertaining as ever, but I’m definitely scarred by a lot of the scenes. Meme it is.
spoilerReview: Ouch. Yeah, I feel that. I’m really sorry for all those explicit scenes, but if you watch these kinds of movies, I guess that’s a given. The slapstick is always funny, I guess. I didn’t really understand the kazakh, so that was a little meh. The main thing is that I felt like a lot of scenes were so well shot that I wondered if maybe they shot them without telling the extras - like the subway scene - but maybe that’s just me being naive. Either way, extras were phenomenal.

title: Brave
rewatchability: Can do once a week if you want
review: “Touch the Sky” is one of the best songs I’ve heard in a WHILE. Disney don’t sleep. It’s such a pity that this movie gets slept on because of Frozen, but it’s actually a solid (very similar) story that’s totally watchable. I thought the over-ethnic scottishness would put me off, but Merida is kinda awesome. The parents, King Fergus (Billy Connoly) and Queen Elinor (Emma Thompson) were some of the best, most realistic parents I’ve seen in Disney movies, and the triplets were cool. All the bear scenes were pretty funny, and Merida overall is such a compelling protagonist. The story isn’t at all complicated, and the archery scene is pretty amazing. Animation is great too. Overall a solid movie.

title: Breakfast at Tiffany’s
intendedAudience: People who like old movies, romance-type
rewatchability: It’s almost 2h, but I wouldn’t rewatch more than once - it’s more like an experience-type movie
review: Aaaaand I’m in love with Audrey Hepburn. What an absolute legend. Even if the movies she’s in aren’t all that amazing, her acting is always super entertaining. Holly’s basically some kind of female Ferris Bueller x Summer (500 days of Summer), so just existing makes her interesting. The nameless cat is hilarious, and shows really good writing in the end. The plot itself was pretty thin, and it’s easy to not like it, but there are loads of quotable lines from Hepburn. “Quelle night!” was super funny to me, but the monologues her character has are also super eloquent. Also the score for this movie is so iconic that I knew what it was without even knowing that I knew it. Still, Holly’s journey is definitely a struggle, and it’s good to watch once.

title: Captain America: The First Avenger
rewatchability: This is a classic type movie, so probably like once a couple months
review: This movie is 2h long, but it’s really an illusion. They have you in the first half an hour, when Steve first takes the serum, and then the last scene is payoff. Everything in between is very classic - you’ve seen it all before, and it’s worth watching again, but it won’t blow your mind. Still, the bar is pretty high, given the MCU’s reputation now. Evans pulls off Rogers in a way that isn’t appreciated nearly enough (for this movie at least), and it’s impossible not to root for him. He’s not as flashy as the other heroes, but nobody can’t like Cap. As for the supporting cast, Bucky (Sebastian Stan) has a wholesome relationship with Steve, Peggy (Hayley Atwell) is kindred spirit, Red Skull (Hugo Weaving) is an okay foil I guess, but Dr. Erskine (Stanley Tucci) would probably be runner-up in this movie - his role in the start is just so important to drawing the audience in. So there’s nazis and flags and stuff, and it’s a very nice hero’s journey to set up the Avengers.

title: Carol
rewatchability: Not exactly light viewing—twice a year tops
review:
As a bit of a skeptic towards romances, the fact that this movie actually impressed me is a pretty solid testament to its quality. Of course, putting Cate Blanchett in a title role isn’t ever going to hurt your film, but the electric chemistry between her character and Rooney Mara’s Therese, the captivating story, and the melancholic score all come together to form a wholly engaging experience. 

Given that Carol comes off as confident and refined past what any actual person would be like, Therese seems to be the character the audience is expected to relate the most to. Her most prominent character struggle is one of what she wants for herself versus what others (her boyfriend, her colleagues, Carol, society) want for her, which is definitely something almost everyone has faced on some level. The only problem is that that indecisiveness makes her a little bland and lacking in agency right up until the very end. We never really get to learn what makes her (or Carol) tick, since their most profound bonding moments are either really meaningful eye contact or chatting drowned out by music. We don’t learn what draws Carol to Therese, which feels like a betrayal of how the movie constantly reminds us how hopelessly lost in love the two of them are. The actual relationship plays second fiddle to the characters’ individual struggles, and I’m fine with that, but not having your central romance hold up feels like a betrayal of your genre. All that said though, great movie, go watch it.

title: Casablanca
intendedAudience: Adults, people who like war-era movies
rewatchability: Once in a year, maybe
review: “Of all the jin joints in all the world… ”, this movie is easily the most quotable. In a way, it shows such an advanced, mature version of “love” not seen in most romance movies. It’s black and white, but it doesn’t seem too old, and it still captures the “war” atmosphere that it no doubt was made in (1942 things). Rick (Humphrey Bogart) was a charismatic protagonist, and had great chemistry with Ilsa (Ingrid Bergman, who’s fairy-like). There’s great performances by Victor Laszlo (Paul Henreid) and Sam (Dooley Wilson), with my personal favorite coming from Louis. I wouldn’t have dreamed of giving a win to a Nazi before, but this guy is hilarious (and, like, barely a nazi anyway). Rick’s cafe is iconic, and this movie has straight up made Casablanca (the city) known. The plot is actually interesting too, and if you don’t know the ending already, it’s definitely something to look forward to. Good production value, too.
spoilerReview: So the best things about this movie were all spoilers, even if its premise was pretty good too. “Here’s looking at you, kid” is obviously the first thing—absolute legends moves. Probably one of the most recognizable catchphrases of a character in movies (if people watch older movies, I guess). And then, of course, the ending line “Louis, I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.” I was so happy. Louis is the best. I laughed when he was like “round up the usual suspects” after Rick literally shot his boss in front of him. Take the win. Then the piano song was super iconic. Also Rick gets maturity points in the end for finding the right solution to the situation (also that one scene where he helped that one kid get money, perfect). And shoutout to Victor for being understanding about Ilsa when she thought he was dead. Everyone in this one is a homie, even if Rick tries to be a tsundere.

title: Chhichhore
intendedAudience: IF YOU’RE AN INDIAN KID IN HIGH SCHOOL OR COLLEGE THIS IS MADE FOR YOU
rewatchability: Once a year, to keep the sentiment fresh
review: In honour of ‘3 Idiots’ and college movies everywhere, I present ‘Chhichhore’. I’m an Indian kid in university right now (off-campus, because pandemic) and I was super happy with my decision until I watched this movie - the spirit of Indian unis is so overpowering and familial that it’s impossible not to yearn for that camaraderie. Maybe it’s just me, since I’m the target audience. The core message of this film is this: you’re only a loser if you think you are, and fighting for yourself is all you can do - and it’ll be enough. Just don’t give up. And I think that’s a message that can be appreciated by everyone. Throw in a cute love story between Anni (Sushant Singh Rajput, who’s great, RIP) and Maya (Shraddha Kapoor, who I love) that’s actually mature enough to be a lesson in and of itself, and an absolutely wonderful supporting cast - Derek (Tahir Basin), Acid (Naveen Polishetty), Mummy (Tushar Pandey), and Bevda (Saharsh Kumar Shukla) - to the greatness that is Sexa, and you have a comedy classic with insane amounts of heart that touches on important issues in society and portrays an authentic (well, mostly, come on) Indian college experience.
spoilerReview: I have to say, that buzzer beater at the end of the basketball game could have gone either way, but I’m glad that’s the message that they went with. The nicknames from all the gang and the kids’ stress about all-india-ranks (btw good job as Raghav, Mohammad Samad) are super relatable, as is, sadly, the boy’s reaction to failure. I do wish they’d given Maya more to do, but it was 2h30, so I understand having to cut out some parts. Still, replaying the doctor scenes wasn’t too integral to the plot or pacing. Of course, the villain appreciating them in the end is a good moral ending, but I also would’ve liked to see a more concrete ending for Anni and Maya’s relationship. Apart from that, the end monologue was great. Oh also, there were basically no songs. Go figure. Anyway, it’s great, and this proves that movies don’t need songs to be good (@Bollywood). Don’t commit suicide, and in honour of Sushant, I hope you enjoy this one.

title: Clueless
intendedAudience: Teens, not young kids, not adults
rewatchability: Couple times a month if you want; wildly rewatchable
review: What if Ferris Bueller had a kid with Regina George? I present the original spoilt, rich girl of the 90s: Cher. This movie is maddd rewatchable, and its high school culture is just really cute to go through. The driving scenes are all hilarious, and the relationships between all the characters are still pretty well fleshed out. Of course, Cher’s house and wardrobe are fabulous, as is the chiq 90s styling for the retro-plastics. Paul Rudd’s Josh stole the show with most scenes (almost enough for me to give him the win), and his chemistry with Silverstone made watching them together really entertaining. Plus, they were both super attractive back in the day. A chick-flick to the finish, this one’s in the bank to keep you entertained on a rainy day.
spoilerReview: Sure, there’s not exactly an important plot, but still, spoilers. I have to say, I don’t know if it’s ambiguous writing, but I didn’t know who was going to end up with who at the end. The only indicator could have been the lack of screentime for Travis, and the fact that Paul Rudd is a lot better known. Their pairing in the end was a little awkward, ex-step siblings and all, but they were both charming enough to pull it off.

title: Coco
rewatchability: Pretty sad story, so maybe once in a year or two
review: This was a good movie, no doubt - I just think that my expectations had been loaded after hearing everyone else’s reviews, and it didn’t feel as mind-blowing as I’d been led on to believe. The theme of remembering family was certainly extremely impactful, and the characters were well-crafted, if a bit annoying. The songs were a highlight, with the acoustic guitar serving as the keystone of the score, with a couple beautiful scenes from Hector. The bridge and guitar design was fabulous to watch, and the idea of ‘spirit guides’ was cool, even if it wasn’t completely necessary. Ernesto’s character was pretty predictable, if one-dimensional, and it might have been a good idea to showcase another aspect of the villain.

title: Coming 2 America
rewatchability: Probably wouldn’t
review: So this one was a nice parody of the first one, with way way less charm and originality. I think they focused on way too many advocacy issues with the characters, and that really took away from the enjoyment of the story. That, and Eddie Murphy works a lot better as the main protagonist as opposed to the antagonist. The funeral scene was super iconic in the start, and I think all the cameos from black celebrities were really cool. Rehashing the barbershop, reverend, McDowell’s, etc. was all okay, I guess.

title: Coming to America
rewatchability: Quite funny overall, could do once in three months
review: I thought Eddie Murphy sounded like Chris Rock, for some reason. Between him and Arsenio Hall, they’re actually really really awesome comedic actors. Around a cast of Lisa (Shari Headley), Patrice (Allison Dean), the King (James Earl Jones), and the Queen (Madge Sinclair), they double and triple-roled their way to a classic. Akeem’s dignity and the movie’s pursuit of challenging western stereotypes about Africa are particularly refreshing. It’s a happy story, but just different enough from modern romcoms to provide that bit of originality to keep you interested.

title: Creed
rewatchability: Once or twice ever
review: Michael B Jordan is a pretty good actor, for sure, and Adonis Creed is an awesome name. The story has a lot of heart, and the boxing scenes are super cool, but the villains are pretty wack. Rocky was the most charismatic person in the movie, and I haven’t even seen the original series yet, so that just does Stallone credit. Tessa Thompson’s Bianca was fun to watch, and Adonis’ step mother was hilarious throughout. The whole Philadelphia feeling was pretty authentic (I think?) and the movie had a nice uprising vibe.

title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon
intendedAudience: People who like action movies, people who don’t mind watching subbed movies
rewatchability: For the action itself, you could watch this every month
review: Can I just say, coolest name for any movie ever. Now, it’s pretty long and has a long plot, but the fight scenes are what make this movie iconic. Li Mu Bai (Chow Yunfat), Yu Shu Lien (Michelle Yeoh), and Jen Yu all fly through the air and over water like it’s nothing, and the effects give it a certain reality that even more modern movies fail to achieve. Definitely something that’s unmatched. Also, this movie is more progressive than most would expect, encouraging an engaged girl to seek her own personal identity and representing two fierce female warriors. The Jade Fox (Cheng Peipei) was a bit much, but Jen Yu’s storyline with The Dark Cloud (Chang Chen) in the desert was fairly enjoyable.

title: Dead Poets Society
rewatchability: Couple times a year, since it’s so dramatic
review: O CAPTAIN MY CAPTAIN. I don’t think there’s an actor in history as Robin Williams, and his performance in this movie is just as good as Sean in Good Will Hunting. This is one of the most quotable movies ever, since it literally has some of humanity’s best literature to draw from, but also because of its iconic as hell characters: Charlie/Nuwanda (Gale Hansen), Neil (Robert Sean Leonard), Knox (Josh Charles), and Todd (Ethan Hawke). As a teen, this is literally the story of our lives, and it’s safe to say that we’d all kill for a teacher like Mr. Keating. Welton has a really elite, Hogwarts-y feeling to it that makes us want to go there, despite how horrible it is. The Dead Poets Society itself is like Terabithia—it might seem like a fantasy, but it’s the truth.

title: Definitely, Maybe
rewatchability: Maybe a couple times, depends
review: So yeah, Ryan Reynolds and his daughter (Abigail Breslin) just have fun trying to out-quip each other in a game of ‘How I Met Your Mother’. It is funny, but there are so many outrageous jokes. There’s a solid cast, with Rachel Weisz and Elizabeth Banks, who are both great too. It suffers the same romcom pitfalls as most, and it does drag on a little bit (2h), and has a LOT of endings (which is funnily most peoples’ criticism of HIMYM). Still, Reynolds is funny, and the daughter is funny too.

title: Despicable Me
rewatchability: Whenever, it’s pretty light-hearted
review: The music in this movie is way better than you’d think. Most people don’t remember it either, but it really helps build the required mood at any point in the story. The minions are great at first watch, especially for kids, if they are in small doses. Overall, the movie has a lot of heart - carried by the girls and Gru’s relationship - which is what makes the story worth the watch. It’s a fun movie, and there’s enough comic relief and standard animated movie things to make it rewatchable.
spoilerReview: Gru’s character arc is great, with his hilarious initial characterisation and his somewhat relatable troubles, to his eventual maturity and happiness with the girls. Vector is surprisingly funny, even if he probably dies in the end. The plot with the bank was pretty boring, and the orphanage lady was pretty much the worst. Agnes’ unicorn obsession is an acceptable amount of cute, and Miranda Cosgrove’s Margot makes up most of the movie along with Steve Carrell’s now-iconic Gru.

title: Django Unchained
rewatchability: Every week if you want, but it’s kinda long
review: Yeah, I like it. Coming from someone who isn’t an out-and-out Tarantino admirer, I think this movie was always a lot easier to get invested with than some of his others, given that it had a plot that was set up from the start. The protagonists - the doctor and Django (Jamie Foxx) - had great chemistry and you could really appreciate the teacher-student bond there. Of course the use of racial profanity for alleged historical accuracy is still pretty uncomfortable for me, but the antagonists were also portrayed with some solid performances including Calvin Candie (Leonardo Di Caprio) and Steven (Samuel L Jackson). Broomhilda’s (Kerry Washington) metaphoric connection to the Poetic Edda was cool, and I think Django’s arc was just really satisfying in the end. Shultz was someone who you always rooted for, and his dialogue (Tarantino special) was always great.

title: Dune
intendedAudience: Book fans definitely, but really anyone into the genre
rewatchability: Depends on preference
review: If I had to sum up my take on this one, I’d probably say that the top-notch direction was masterclass-worthy, but the relatively average script kept it from being something really special. The entire movie is a joy to look at—for a relatively limited color palette, Denis Villeneuve does an incredible job crafting beautiful shots that perfectly convey the movie’s scale and overall atmosphere. Visual storytelling and attention to detail is unbelievable too. I’m serious, if it was possible to have a director win one of these, I would absolutely give Villeneuve first place without hesitation. Acting was pretty great across the board, but there weren’t particular standout performances. The narrative structure was a little wonky, probably because this was a part one, and I think that the lack of proper setups and payoffs made it harder to get properly invested in the plot. Pretty great overall though, definitely an impressive adaptation of some weighty source material.

title: Easy A
rewatchability: 3,4 times a year maybe
review: I’m not going to say that Emma Stone saved this movie, but her unique voice gave the “narration”-type structure a lot of life, and her acting was certainly fresh and believable in the teen-protagonist role (particularly with sarcasm). If there was any movie that I’d compare this movie to, it’d be Mean Girls - there’s an impressive cast (Stanley Tucci, Amanda Bynes, Lisa Kudrow, Patricia Clarkson), a unique protagonist, and an awkward, self-aware tone that hits home for a very specific audience. And while both were incredibly similar in terms of tone, I feel like this movie was a little less well-executed, and more awkward (not in a good way). But might be cool to watch with friends.

title: Ender’s Game
rewatchability: The first time is the most important, but it’s really entertaining for 2h
review: Can I just say, SUPER underrated movie. Let’s set the record straight - plotwise, we have the novel by Orson Scott Card to thank, and it is SPECTACULAR. You’ll be hard-pressed to find a more compelling sci-fi plot than this one. The conclusion alone is worthy of classifying the whole movie as a thriller. Then the acting; Asa is wonderfully expressive as the young Ender (his voice cracks are especially emotive), and Harrison Ford as Colonel Graff is pretty great to watch too. Petra (Hailee Steinfeld before she was famous), Valentine (Abigail Breslin) and Mazer Rackham (Ben Kingsley) are both also pretty great supporting characters. The technology and word-building of the future - the space stations and battle room in particular - is beautiful, and the score and direction (zooming into Ender’s eyes a lot) really helps develop the emotion of the characters.
spoilerReview: THAT ENDING. Definitely one of the best endings in movie history. And the expression on Ender’s face is definitely powerful enough to capture just how terrible his realization felt. The buildup to the final scene, with the Mind Game and whatnot, was all done pretty well, and the pressure definitely progressed in a way that kept the stakes higher than ever. Plus, the battle room scenes are just the most fun ever.

title: Enola Holmes
intendedAudience: Young generation to take action, older generation to check their biases, sherlock holmes fans
rewatchability: Once a year maybe
review: So this wasn’t bad. It was a netflix movie, and it was marketed pretty well. Enola breaks the fourth wall a lot, so that’s definitely fun to watch. Obviously, this movie isn’t perfect, with Mycroft (Sam Claflin) being completely intolerable for the first half, and Sherlock (Henry Cavill) being completely watered down (especially after watching the BBC Sherlock). But otherwise, Enola was likeable, and she had great chemistry with Lord Tewksbury (Louis Partridge). A supporting cast of Helena Bonham Carter as the mom and Fiona Shaw was fun, staying true to the British theme of the cast. The story itself wasn’t bad, if a little disjointed, but the moral was extremely relevant to 2020’s audience (what with all the protests and human rights campaigns), and it was pulled off well.

title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
rewatchability: You might have to rewatch a couple times, but it’s pretty exciting for most of it
review: I quite like the premise of the movie - the ability to erase someone from your memory is definitely a unique idea in regards to romance movies, and I think they pulled it off pretty well. Joel Barrish (Jim Carrey) and Clementine had great chemistry; I didn’t know Jim Carrey was a good dramatic actor, but I do now. There’s a massive supporting cast here, too, with Stan (Mark Ruffalo), Mary (Kirsten Dunst), Patrick (Elijah Wood), Rob (David Cross), and Howard (Tom Wilkinson), and their exciting little characters all help compensate for the lack of action for the leads. That said, the memory jumping structure and direction was outstanding and unique, if a little jarring, and the cuts really helped the pacing of the movie. A lot of the dialogue was great (Nietzsche quotes) and Patrick’s manipulation of the memory-wipe system is also super important in terms of speculative science fiction. Still, Clementine’s Manic Pixie Dream Girl persona shines through and her bright hair and clothes definitely contrast well with Joel’s. There’s some comedy there, lots of drama, and a compelling romance. Definitely an interesting romance movie.

title: Ex Machina
rewatchability: You wouldn’t really, but it’s 1h45 and mostly idealistic
review: Damn, this was pretty jarring. So basically it’s about Caleb (Domnhall Gleeson) who’s selected to go meet the famous Zuckerberg-type Nathan (Oscr Isaac) to Turing Test out the new AI, Ava (Alicia Vikander). The idea and the execution is definitely very professional and well-researched, creating the uncomfortable mood that would no doubt surround any ordeal of that sort - this helps keep tension, but it’s also hard to watch. The direction, music, cinematography, dialogue is all great, and I think Ava is definitely an interesting take on an inorganic human. The plot does make sense in its own little arc, but it does give off a relatively cautionary feeling that would have been identified regardless of the ending.
spoilerReview: Oof. Nathan was super creepy. His relationship with Ava creeped me out. Ava was super sweet at the start, but her totally abandoning Caleb at the end was pretty weird for me, even if she did just manipulate him (which is disappointing). I pretty much guessed Kyoko/Katie (Sonoyo Mizuno) was a robot also, but the cupboard full of extras was creepy. Pretty scary overall.

title: Ferris Bueller’s Day Off
intendedAudience: Wonderful for teens and below; Adults should enjoy too
rewatchability: Pretty rewatchable, just don’t overdo it
review: Honestly this is the best movie ever made. From the first second of it to the last, I wasn’t once tempted to take my eyes off of it. The characters were great, and they complimented each other well. This movie has some heart, and is just a whole lot of fun. There’s a lot of different tones in the movie, but they never feel disjointed. Of course, the soundtrack is legendary, featuring songs by the Beatles and even the Star Wars Theme. The movie’s representation of peak 1900s culture is so good that if I had to show aliens one movie to give them an impression of humans it would be this. Ferris Bueller’s effortless charm and wit makes him possibly the most likeable character of all time - certainly in my book. Mia Sara’s Sloane is insanely good looking and has a sophisticated grace that makes her character so much more than just a supporting role. Of course, Cameron was the heart of the movie, and his relationship with the Ferrari was both hilarious and fabulous character growth. Gene’s character growth was also immensely satisfying, as was Rooney’s ultimate downfall. This will forever be my go-to movie.

title: Five Feet Apart
intendedAudience: Solo is best, maybe with a quiet friend
rewatchability: Once a year
review: The chemistry between Hayley Lu Richardson and Cole Sprouse is adorable and completely believable - makes the movie. Doesn’t hurt that they’re super attractive, either. Score wasn’t exactly legendary, but it played its part really well, upheld the feels whenever it needed to. Has an incredible amount of heart, and it’ll get you thinking about things you might not think about usually - privilege of being healthy, having the chance to be with others, taking chances, etc. Better to watch alone, or at least with people who don’t talk a lot, so that you can appreciate it.
spoilerReview: Ending messed me up. Straight up. Crying. Ending messed me up. Straight up. Crying. The pool scene was adorable, of course. Abby’s whole existence was alright at first, but a bit annoying later on; I recognize her importance to Stella’s character, so all is forgiven. Poe was much better than I thought he’d be – Moises Arias did a pretty solid job. The nurse’s relationship with her was really sweet, and I think that the youtube highlights were Stella’s opus. Birthday scene was great, and Cole really showed off his acting chops – facial expressions especially. May have been a bit long, but is definitely worth rewatching once a year.

title: Flavors of Youth
rewatchability: 1h15, but it’s also like 3 episodes, so you can spread it out
review: Bruh get that kid his noodles. Get that woman her sister. Get the guy Xiao Yu. That’s basically what the three episodes are about (they link up in the post-credits). I personally liked the third the best, but this is why the audience is so wide - each of them appeal to different age groups. Overall, the animation is pretty good, and the music and narration are the cornerstones of what makes the episodes so heartfelt. The first part will make you hungry with all that noodle talk, but it shows how much affect you might have on the lives of people you don’t even know. The second part is probably for more mature-minded viewers, having to do with self-realization. Yi Lin (Minako Kotobuki) and Lulu (Jona Xiao) have a really touching sibling relationship as adults, which isn’t depicted too often. The third part is a romance-drama (which I really liked) with Xiao Yu (who’s adorable) and Li Mo (Takeo Otsuka), in circumstances that you might even recognize.
spoilerReview: REAL QUICK: Xiao Yu throwing the exam for Li Mo got me BAD. I realized it just before she said it, and it hit so hard when the scene came around. Tears. Also her abusive dad is really not okay (who puts their own kid in the hospital?). But yeah, I think some aspects of all three stories are relatable to any viewer, and the ending really shows that there’s a happy possibile future for any past.

title: Ford v Ferrari
rewatchability: Action is great, but story hits the hardest the first time
review: I didn’t know who Ken Miles and Carroll Shelby were before watching, and now I have such a profound respect for them. Racing is sometimes a niche sport - I always thought it was too dangerous and unrelatable - but it’s definitely wonderful to watch in movies. Matt Damon is great as Shelby, and even though Christian Bale’s cockney accent was a little surprising, I think he did a phenomenal job as Ken (who I think deserves a lot of the credit here too). Mollie (Caitriona Balfe) is awesome in support, and Peter (Noah Jupe) has some important scenes. The shooting was great, the practical effects were wonderful, and the costumes were definitely awesome. Solid job.
spoilerReview: THEY WARNED US! They hinted at it. It wasn’t enough. I took such a blow when Ken died, man. That just seemed cruel. And what’s worse is that this all actually happened in real life. Honestly that Ford executive dude was the absolute most annoying antagonist I’ve ever seen - and I mean including Joffrey and Ramsay. The slowing down thing was more insufferable than if he’d crashed out. That voice over and the last scene are really nice though, and I hope the kid has a nice life.

title: Forrest Gump
intendedAudience: With some censorship, maybe kids could watch it
review: For a movie that tackled subject matter as heavy as this one did, watching it was considerably easier than one would think. Personally, the anti-tarantino style of historical narration and modification was addictively entertaining, and the plot itself was well crafted. Of course, Hanks’ most iconic role is that for a reason, and Forrest Gump is probably one of the most likeable movie protagonists ever - his straightforward demeanor and underdog persona makes rooting for him completely seamless and fulfilling. The subtle musical and theatrical expertise of the crew make this movie what it is, with the narrative style and the opening and closing shots adding an artistic edge to an already thematically sound film. The supporting cast did well, with Lieutenant Dan (Gary Sinise) completing his own meaningful character arc adjacent to Forrest’s. Add a couple lines of completely iconic dialogue, and it makes a solid council class movie.
spoilerReview: I guess I feel for Jenny, given that she has a tough childhood and all, but Forrest deserved better.

title: Friends With Benefits
rewatchability: Once in a couple months
review: So I originally thought this movie would be a lot dirtier than it was, and I think it’s important that people know that it’s really not. It’s got the standard romcom ratio of that stuff, nothing disproportionate. Jamie and Dylan (Justin Timberlake) are the mains, and they have pretty great chemistry. Even though both of their characters are messed up, they both seem interesting enough to be super likeable. Both NY and LA are exploited to the fullest, and I quite enjoy it. My only problem with the plot was the third act, which slowed the tempo in a pretty romcom way, and I felt like maybe it wasn’t the best move for this story. Still, the ending was cool, and all the interactions between the mains were hilarious and entertaining. Solid romcom.

title: Frozen 2
intendedAudience: Kids movie, but pretty much everyone
rewatchability: Once a month-ish should be okay if wanted, it’s not too long
review: Although Disney sequels to classics are typically subpar in comparison to its predecessors, Frozen 2 holds its ground quite well, which is impressive considering how good the original is. Elsa was a lot more likeable this time around - and this is coming from an Anna stan - and all of the songs that she was involved in were stellar. Anna’s plot wasn’t as refined as it was in the first one, but her song at the end of the movie more than made up for it. Kristoff, Olaf, and Sven were decent comedy aids, keeping the tempo of a generally somber movie relatively upbeat, while managing to not disrupt its tone. The main issue with this film, though, was pacing. The movie spends most of its time setting up its character conflicts instead of developing them, so the ending is forced to tie everything together with a neat little bow. Frozen II’s final half hour or so felt a bit disjoint from the rest of the movie because of that.
spoilerReview: The movie’s premise itself was a lot more interesting than I had thought it would be, and full credit is due to the scriptwriters. The whole plot line with the mother was really cool too, so much so that I was considering giving her the win over Elsa, despite her lack of actual presence in the movie. Even though it was obvious, the resurrection of both Elsa and Olaf simultaneously was pretty off-putting, but the final proposal made the feels seem requited. The water-horse was pretty cool too.

title: Ghostbusters
rewatchability: Pretty funny, once in a couple years
review: Who you gonna call? That song is still awesome. The cast for this movie is great, and it’s not hard to see why it’s a cult classic - Venkman, Ray (Dan Aykroyd), Egon Spengler (Harold Ramis), and later Winston (Ernie Hudson) were the perfect nuclear team, and between their chemistry and the movie’s fun premise and upbeat tone, it’s definitely a fun watch. There is a lot of wasted time with Dana (Sigourney Weaver) and her plot with Louis (Rick Moranis), but the ending scene was definitely hilarious. Big shout to Janine (Annie Potts), who’s hilarious.
spoilerReview: Crossing streams is now like a big thing in pop-culture, which just goes to show how cool the ending was. Of course, the marshmallow man scene is absolutely wonderful. Also, I really really hate that environmental agency guy. Couldn’t tolerate him at all, and I wasn’t entirely sure what turning the machine off would do. Still, the ending was nice, and the music is awesome.

title: Gifted
rewatchability: Maybe once every few years to see if you get anything new out of it
review: Wow yeah, pretty good movie. It’s a little weird seeing Chris Evans as anything other than Captain America, but he keeps his honest, good-natured face with Frank Adler. His interactions with Mary are really cute, and they have really great chemistry. McKenna Grace is crazy good for a child actor in drama. Evelyn (Lindsay Duncan) is the biggest part apart from those two, and I think she’s played pretty well, which makes me absolutely hate her that much more. Bad parenting in movies really really triggers me. But yeah Frank’s story was really well done, and I have to say he’s ridiculously well adjusted (although that might just be the captain america residue). The music was nice, the dialogue was pretty good, and I thought the direction was interesting too. There’s a lot of heart and a real debate as to how to treat a kid’s potential, and all the math scenes are pretty cool. It’s definitely important to see what makes the difference in these arguments, and I think Frank’s sincerity is the most important thing to take away. Fred the Cat gets extra points because Mary loves him.
spoilerReview: The shadow of Mary’s mom was important, and the reveal at the end was definitely awesome. I definitely thought that Evelyn got a way better ending than she deserved, and that Frank should have absolutely dunked on her. But I guess that’s his charm. Bonnie (Jenny Slate) was pretty funny and important in the first half, but she fades a bit in the finale. Roberta (Octavia Spencer) is really nice as well, and helped share information with the audience without exposition. Plus her karaoke scene was funny.

title: Goal 2: Living the Dream
rewatchability: Prob wouldn’t
review: Yeah so this movie isn’t exactly something you would look forward to, especially since it doesn’t really have a plot. The fact that there are a bunch of famous footballers is quite impressive, but also the movie itself could have done better with what was undoubtedly a big budget. The whole Enrique plot kinda pised me off too.

title: Gods of Egypt
intendedAudience: People who like mythology, people who like fantasy
rewatchability: Couple times a year
review: It looks bad, but it’s really not. Films like this are usually marketed in a way that just makes them seem useless, but it was enjoyable. Bek and Zaya’s (Courtney Eaton) romance was heart-warming, Horus (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) and Hathor (Elodie Yung) were pretty god-like, and Thoth (Chadwick Boseman) was so weird. So hit and miss, I guess, but mostly pretty solid. Set (Gerard Butler) was a cool villain, and his arc made sense mostly. Either way, watching a mortal talk back to gods is entertaining enough to come back to. I don’t really mind the whitewashed cast, but I’m not Egyptian, so… either way, I would definitely choose acting over accuracy in that way, even if it’s just me. CGI really didn’t hold up in some fights, and one of the initial cuts was SO BAD, but mostly it’s good to watch. Bit overstuffed with myths and stuff, but the main story isn’t bad.

title: Good Will Hunting
intendedAudience: Not a light-hearted film, so definitely for a more mature kind of audience
rewatchability: Couple times a year, since it’s so dramatic
review: Another classic - I’d watch this movie any day. To think that it was written by Matt Damon and Ben Affleck too makes it that much more special, and its sheer genuine-ness makes it easy to love. Will is a legendary protagonist, with the whole movie being centered around his character arc, facilitated by Sean (Robin Williams), who was a close second-best performance. Their chemistry was indescribable, and made the movie to such an extent that most of the movie was just them sitting in a room and talking to each other. Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgard) was a believable human character, Skylar (Minnie Driver) was a likeable human love-interest, and Chuckie and Morgan (Ben and Casey Affleck) were a great complementary cast to round out Damon’s scenes. The dialogue was incredibly iconic, with “Carmine Scarpaglia”, “How’d you like them apples”, and a lot of outbursts making the movie insanely entertaining. Artistically, the movie wasn’t lacking either, and its background music was a solid complementary piece whenever it appeared.

title: Hamilton
intendedAudience: People who like musicals, people who are interested in history
rewatchability: Not frequently, maybe once a year max
review: Well I’m not a broadway guy, but I appreciate vocals, and Lin Manuel Miranda is a certified legend. From the opening scene (which kinda spoils itself) the music is great, and all the performers really fit their parts wonderfully. Miranda is great and captivating as Alexander Hamilton. Thomas Jefferson (Daveed Diggs) and George Washington (Christopher Jackson) are really fitting as the respected presidents, while Leslie Odom Jr.’s Aaron Burr is a pleasant surprise (but also the character that takes the most Ls). Jonathan Groff’s King George III was a really nice comedic angle, reminiscent of Shakespeare’s Puck. Most characters had really fulfilling and believable arcs, and I feel like I learned a bit, so that’s good. If you’re going to give oscars to any non-commercial movies, this is the way to go.

title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban
rewatchability: 2h20, but the plot is great, and you’re invested throughout
review: Probably the best one out of the 8 movies, if it’s possible to rank them. This one utilizes Harry’s backstory to the absolute maximum, bringing back characters with such an emotional stake in his life that the plot actually seems like it might affect his development. Harry (Daniel Radcliffe), Ron (Rupert Grint), Hermione (Emma Watson) were hitting their stride as actors in this movie, Daniel in particular, and I think Draco (Tom Felton) played a really important comedic role. The adults were obviously more prolific; Michael Gambon’s Dumbledore was probably at his best in his debut here, while Snape (Alan Rickman), Sirius (Gary Oldman), and Remus were all phenomenal near the end. Hagrid (Robbie Coltrane) and Buckbeak’s storyline wasn’t the most exciting, but it worked really well with the plot in the end. The DADA class remains one of the best scenes overall, and of course the Patronus scene was probably the most iconic Harry Potter scene ever.
spoilerReview: Well everyone’s already seen this, but I’m sure the twist with Peter Pettigrew (Timothy Spall) being Scabbers and the real traitor was pretty shocking at the time. The reunion between Sirius and Remus is great to watch, as are both of their reactions to Harry (recognizing his eyes, etc.). I think the Marauders storyline is one of the absolute best parts of Harry Potter, and this movie utilizes it the most out of any of them. Hogsmeade, the Marauders’ Map, everything was pretty well done. Ron was pretty annoying in this one though, even if that scene with them eating the beans was cool. Marge was awful (rightly so) and the Knight Bus scene was pretty random, I guess. Dementors were definitely on point.

title: Hitman’s Bodyguard
intendedAudience: Not bad for large groups, but not with parents
rewatchability: No spoilers really, and mostly action and comedy
review: This movie is what you’d expect from a Sam Jackson and Ryan Reynolds movie. The action is entertaining, there’s a bit of heart, and they have decent chemistry. Between Elodie Yung and Salma Hayek, the cast are pretty good looking, and the comedy is definitely worth a watch. Lots of swearing, as you’d think, and some decent dialogue from Jackson.

title: Hotarubi no Mori e
intendedAudience: Teens, people who remember their childhoods fondly
rewatchability: 45m only, so you can rewatch weekly
review: These kinds of movies are just so artsy that sometimes it’s hard to appreciate them. This movie, though, has the iconic cat-mask-wearing Gin, who’s got a tragic backstory that means he can’t touch anyone. Then there’s Hotaru (Ayane Sakura) who grows up from a six year-old to a high school student, and her journey in this short movie is almost as tragic as Gin’s. They do have a pretty heartwarming relationship, but the animation, music, narration, and supporting characters really do help to build a world that supports their story and seems authentic. The last scene is honestly really sad, but felt inevitable, and there are a lot of beautiful shots in the movie. I feel like it might be an allegory for children and their imagination, but I’m not sure how the ending would factor into that. Still, it was definitely great value for time, and I think it’s worth a recommend.

title: Howl’s Moving Castle
intendedAudience: Studio Ghibli fans, anime fans, animation fans
rewatchability: I think rewatches are necessary to understand
review: Bruh why are these movies so hard to understand. Straight up, apart from marvelling at how good everything looks, I really don’t see what’s going on with this movie. The antiwar message was pretty overt, but it was conveyed more through the setting and visuals than the actual plot progression. I guess the characters and the art style were super abstract, which is cool, and very typical Miyazaki, but the plot itself was so hard to make concrete sense of. The castle design was cool, for sure, too. I know it’s based on a book, and from what I can tell, the original narrative made way more sense. Still, it’s interesting to watch and think about, so give it a try.
spoilerReview: Let’s see if we can understand this, shall we? So someone cursed a prince and turned him into a turnip scarecrow (best character), which started a war. Suliman used the war as an excuse to fight all other wizards, including Howl, who rejected her teachings and became a half-demon with the help of Calcifer (also a legend). They fight a lot, and Suliman tricks the Witch of the Waste and steals her power. More fighting, more drama, until eventually Sophie kisses the turnip and his curse is lifted, ending the war. Pretty random way to go about it. Howl I guess has a character arc, which is nice. Markl, the kid, is pretty much just there, though his dynamic with Sophie is pretty cute to watch. The witch gets annoying near the end. The whole aging business is super motif-like, which I guess is cool. Still hella confusing.

title: In the Heights
rewatchability: 2h30, but good songs
review: Usnavi is a pretty cool name, even if its origin is super stupid (still realistic). Lin-Manuel Miranda is awesome at writing, and Anthony Ramos is a pretty good protagonist, even if this movie is carried by its “community” feeling and cast. Vanessa (Melissa Barrera) is pretty cool, and Nina (Leslie Grace) is a cool kind of character who goes through a journey that isn’t too prominent in the movies. Plus, Leslie Grace is awesome. Carla (Stephanie Beatriz) is funny, and Benny (Corey Hawkins) has some really great scenes - especially the gravity-defying dance. There’s a lot of heart in this movie, and I enjoyed the little insertions of Spanish here and there in the dialogue. The changing POVs gave us the chance to view the community from every perspective. Sonny (Gregory Diaz IV) was definitely a great piece to add, and the colours everywhere made the movie much easier to watch.

title: Independence Day
rewatchability: 2h30, start is slow, end is awesome
review: Think about the two most typecast actors in Hollywood, and put them in the same movie. This movie has Will Smith as Steve and Jeff Goldblum as David as its leads, and it somehow makes both of them seem even more charismatic than they usually are. A supporting cast of Bill Pullman, Randy Quaid as the legend himself, and Margaret Colin as Connie all give great dramatic performances in the tense atmosphere that this movie thrives on. The start is definitely slow, the second act has its gems, but the third act of this movie is one of the best third acts you’ll see in action movies. Also the dialogue here is insanely iconic, so shoutout to the writers; for a 2h30 movie to be so rewatchable is definitely a credit.
spoilerReview: HELLO BOYS, I’M BAACK. That was definitely awesome, come on. Also THAT presidential speech gave me total goosebumps and won Pullman the movie then and there - man, I wish the US had a president like that. But yeah, Will and Goldblum both do phenomenal jobs with what they’re given, and it’s a pity they only meet in the third act, because their chemistry in that last scene is so eyecatching. And that final shot with them walking in the desert? Chef’s kiss. I’ll also never stop laughing at Will Smith punching an alien.
