title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom
rewatchability: Whenever you’re bored
review: Yeah no it was pretty weird man. Every non-white character was insufferable, and out of the two white ones, the girl (Winnie, Kate Capshaw) was really annoying for like 95% of the movie. Indiana Jones himself makes the movie worth watching, kinda like Jack Sparrow in the later Pirates of the Caribbean movies. The kid (Shortie, Jonathan Ke Quan) was so annoying and unnecessary, and I didn’t even understand what he was saying most of the time. The music, however, was great throughout, and the costumes weren’t bad at all. Cast chemistry was pretty good, and the action was nice- particularly the minecart scene at the end. The bridge scene had pretty good suspense too. The main reason it’s not just Existent is that it’s got a lot of heart (and not just the ones that are ripped out of peoples’ chests).

title: Inglourious Basterds
intendedAudience: Tarantino fans, but also anyone who isn’t a nazi
rewatchability: Every week if you want, but it’s kinda long
review: I’m not exactly a Tarantino fan, but I was pleasantly surprised with this movie. Its “highs” were really high, and I bet it definitely goes down as a guilty pleasure movie for a lot of people. Tarantino’s reinvention of history is really entertaining, especially with the characters of Hans Lamda and Brad Pitt’s Aldo Raine, both of whose unique characters are insanely entertaining to watch. The length of this movie is an issue, as it is with most Tarantino movies, taking out some of the urgency from the story. Otherwise, the opening was constructed beautifully, and the character introductions were iconic. The cast was certainly impressive; Brad Pitt, Christoph Waltz, Michael Fassbender, Diane Kruger, Melanie Laurent, Daniel Bruhl. The portrayal of Hitler is also pretty hilarious to watch, and is very much in tone with the rest of the movie’s theme - the cinemafiction of one of the biggest tragedies in human history (WWII).

title: Interstellar
rewatchability: SUPER emotive, so maybe once in a couple years (?)
review: As he tends to do, Nolan brings in the powerhouses for Interstellar’s cast, including but not limited to Matthew McConaughey, Anne Hathaway, Michael Caine, Matt Damon, and surprisingly not Leo DiCaprio. The premise is solid, and the visuals and score are on another level. The movie plays with different aspects of humanity, celebrating our legacy as pioneers and our capacity for love while looking down on our drive for individual self-preservation and fear of the unknown. The chemistry between McConaughey’s character and his daughter is played to its fullest, and their connection is a focal point for the entire movie. There’s a fair amount of religious symbolism as well, but it all takes the form of concrete human achievement, which seems to tell us that even miracles can be made possible by ingenuity and perseverance.
spoilerReview:
I'm gonna lead off by saying that the moment where Mann betrays Cooper, Brand rescues him, the camp explodes, and Murph torches the cornfield might just be my favorite scene in all of cinema. There are probably more iconic or critically acclaimed examples out there, but everything about this set piece is just amazing. From the nerve-wracking score to the constant cutting between everything going around to the exceptional performances from literally everyone, I can never take my eyes off the screen when this part is on.

On another note, I totally get the criticisms of how the third act tried to be too brilliant for its own good. I find myself having to explain the tesseract scene to basically everyone I watch this movie with, which is fair, since I spent an hour or so reading about it after I first saw it in theaters. But hey—this is a Nolan movie, after all, and that pitfall was completely to be expected.

Seeing Murph on her deathbed hit different. I don't know what to say. The words "No parent should have to watch their own child die" left me feeling devastated at all the years she and Cooper should've been able to spend together as father and daughter that she'd had to live out on her own.

title: Ip Man
intendedAudience: People who like martial arts movies
rewatchability: 1h40, and lots of action, but pretty serious subject matter
review: So apparently this is basically a true story, which is crazy. It’s about this guy called Ip Man (that’s his actual name) in the 1940s when Japan took over China. He’s great at fighting the wing chun style, and he taught Bruce Lee. So you already know he’s going to be THAT guy. It’s mostly a historical (dramaticized, of course) rendition of the occupation in the eyes of the Chinese, and Ip’s reaction to the situation. Great fight scenes, Lynn Hung is great as Cheung, and it’s good as a fighting movie.

title: Jumanji: The Next Level
intendedAudience: People who enjoy funny blockbuster-type movies
rewatchability: Once a month if you want, but you probably wouldn’t want
review: Gotta love Jumanji, huh? This movie is always going to be thought of in terms of the first movie (Jumanji: Into the Jungle), whose blending of cast in the ‘real’ and video-game worlds made a uniquely impactful movie that was also fun to watch repeatedly. This movie has that too, just to a lesser precedent. The emotional quotient was kept high throughout, with solid acting from Danny DeVito, Danny Glover, and Alex Wolff, while the action is handled by Dwayne Johnson and Karen Gillan, leaving the comedy to Kevin Hart and Jack Black. Suffice to say, the cast speaks for itself in terms of competence, and they definitely have chemistry too, with everyone doing what they were expected to, and also working a little outside of their comfort zones. The world was also enhanced from the previous movie, while not seeming much like a ret-con, which was also a welcome addition to the story and continuity of the movies. The grievances lie mostly in that it tried to do a lot, and that the execution was a bit less on-the-nose as it had been in the previous movie. Overall, still a fun watch.
spoilerReview: The horse thing was a bit much, and the pegasus thing was sufficiently much. Again, the viking villain guy was pretty bad, meaning that they really didn’t learn from their mistakes from the last movie. They lost way too many lives throughout, and Milo’s (Danny Glover) way of talking was proper annoying.

title: Juno
rewatchability: Couple times ever
review: So this is basically Quirkiness: The Movie. I guess that’s what you should expect from Ellen Page and Michael Cera. It’s not bad, and there’s some pretty good banter throughout the movie. Jennifer Garner was kinda annoying in it, but JK Simmons wasn’t bad. Juno pretty much carried it by herself, and it really helped show how charming Ellen Page is. Otherwise, the whole story about teen pregnancy is all believable and feels important. It’s portrayed in a way that feels really chill and easy to watch. I really didn’t like Michael Cera’s outfit, though.

title: Jurassic Park
intendedAudience: Anyone really, might be scary for kids
rewatchability: Multiple times a month, but novelty plays a big part
review: So I don’t think I was meant to watch Jurassic World before this one, so my pov might be a little unfair, but I still thought this movie was pretty good. The b-plots were pretty annoying, and the setup at the beginning wasn’t really too required, but the main cast of Sam Neill, Laura Dern, and Jeff Goldblum carried pretty well. The kids weren’t too annoying, and their relationship with Alan (Neill) was pretty nice to watch as the movie progressed. Action-wise it was pretty good for 1993, and a few set-pieces still hold up pretty well. Music fits wonderfully, because JOHN WILLIAMS. I wish there was a proper main character in this movie though, it might have helped with clarity.

title: Jurassic World
rewatchability: Once a month if you want
review: Yeah, I loved it. As someone who hasn’t ever seen any one of the original Jurassic Park movies from start to finish, but still has a general idea of the iconic scenes, this was perfect for me. Definitely makes sense that this is the 6th highest grossing movie ever, and I think it did justice to the originals. The cast is loaded, with Chris Pratt (Owen) and Bryce Dallas Howard (Claire) leading the movie as adults (with pretty great chemistry and dialogue) and Ty Simpkins (Gray) and Nick Robinson (Zack) playing the child-self-insert characters that visit the resort. Vincent D’Onofrio, Irrfan Khan, Katie McGrath, Judy Greer, etc. make a pretty stellar supporting cast too. The visual experience was awesome, and the colors made the park seem like a lot more than just a CGI paradise. The dinosaurs were cool, and the park was impressive. Giacchino’s score was pretty beautiful, and it took from the original Jurassic Park theme (if it ain’t broke) too, so best of both worlds. The plotlines make a lot of sense, and none of the characters seem unjustified in their actions, which is a refreshing surprise for a blockbuster. The action also really doesn’t disappoint. The acting is great, and the relationships between the brothers, the adults, and Claire and the kids have a lot of heart too, which keeps the stakes high. Blue was awesome, and he gets a honorary win (everyone did pretty well this time around, which is part of what made this movie that good).
spoilerReview: Bruh that final fight tho. Like I’d seen what happened before, but with context, that SLAPS. The TRex and raptor vs Indominus? Get outa here. I should have seen this in the cinema ngl. The final KING roar at the end gave me goosebumps, so good job guys. The shot with the flare and the TRex is cool, and the raptor scene w Owen as the alpha is cool too. Solid effort.

title: Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom
intendedAudience: People who liked the first one, people who like action movies
rewatchability: Once a month if you want
review: This one starts a bit slow, especially in comparison to the first movie, and its cast isn’t as stacked. Still, it has a good progression, and a lot of the set-pieces are really fun to watch. Pratt and Bryce Dallas Howard’s chemistry is once again really captivating, and even though the Maisie Lockhart (Isabella Sermon) b-story might seem frustrating at first, it pays off with some pretty good story potential in the end. The villain wasn’t really as good as last time, and the new comic relief duo weren’t as relatable as the brothers from the last film, but in terms of watchability, it’s pretty solid.
spoilerReview: So the scene with them floating away from the park on the barge, watching the bracchio die was pretty sad. The whole die-hard thing that they had going on at the estate was cool too, and would have been fun to see more of. The TRex didn’t do much, but its establishing ‘roar’ shot was pretty satisfying. The science guys were pretty boring. Indo Raptor was a discount Indominus Rex, really nothing in comparison to the first villain in terms of awesomeness. Blue did clutch up though, which is good. The ending was pretty mad in terms of consequences, and it’ll be cool to see how they continue. Also Goldblum’s cameo wasn’t the best.

title: Just Go With It
intendedAudience: Definitely great to watch with friends
rewatchability: Total popcorn, would be fine to rewatch in a couple months
review: Haha. I’ve been searching for an alternative movie to We’re the Millers for a while now, and I’m really glad to have found this. Sure, it’s not exactly the same, and I might not have laughed as hard consistently, but it’s really a great time. Daniel (Adam Sandler) and Katherine have ridiculous chemistry throughout, and Palmer (Brooklyn Decker) is a darling, not to mention a real-life model. The kids are also hilarious plot devices, and I think that the sheep scene with Eddie (Nick Swardson) was probably the one that got me laughing the hardest.

title: Karate Kid
intendedAudience: Kids, teens, people who like happy-message movies
rewatchability: Quite rewatchable, but 2h, so maybe once in a couple of  weeks is possible
review: I feel like this movie gets way less credit than it deserves. I understand that the original was super iconic to some people, but there’s a distinct difference between the two movies (even if the plot itself was starkly similar) - The first was about visiting oriental culture in the west, while this one was about a westerner dealing with chinese culture IN china. There’s a difference. Oh, and the other one was actually Karate and Japan/Okinawa. Still, both are great. Jaden smith was a pretty loveable protagonist, and his chemistry with both Mr. Han (Jackie Chan) and his mom (Taraji P Henson) was great. Wenwen Han was cute as Meiying, and the exploration of cultural divide and assimilation was great to view from a kid’s eyes. I actually loved how nice this movie was to China - even the opening credits were in Chinese, which I found really cool. The music, score, and everything was phenomenal, the cinematography and establishing shots were great, and there was a lot of emotional weight in the main character’s arc, which is what made the final scene so great. Anyway, it’s a fun watch for kids, and definitely helps capture the experience of overcoming challenges as a kid.

title: Knives Out
intendedAudience: Pretty universal; maybe not the youngest of kids, since swearing and explicit language
rewatchability: Once or twice a month if wanted, but it’s 2+ hours long, so time-constraints might be an issue
review: This movie’s cast was so stacked that pretty much everyone in the world would have to know at least one of them: Ana de Armas, Daniel Craig, Michael Shannon, Chris Evans, Katherine Langford, Jamie Lee Curtis, and more. For a two-hour movie, it didn’t ever feel overly boring, but I guess that’s the plus point of detective stories. Christopher Plummer’s Harlan Thrombey started the film out on a really sincere note, and his chemistry with Ana was pretty good to watch. Chris and Ana also carried the middle section of the movie, while Craig held all of it together. There’s enough comedy in it to keep the movie from getting too stale, even if some of it is rather tasteless, but the tone of the film is the real hero, keeping it light hearted through the color palette and dialogue.
spoilerReview: Craig may have been a standout acting-wise, but mixed feelings on the accent. Definitely wasn’t the James Bond voice we’ve come to expect from him. The ending wasn’t bad, but it wasn’t exactly revolutionary either. Definitely a lot of heart though, and it was great to see Marta (de Armas) come into her own. While the specifics of how may have been a mystery, though, it felt inevitable from the start that she’d come out on top. Overall, I think it is a good watch, especially in recent years, since it fits in with the anti-money-grab message that needs to be heard at the moment.

title: Kung Fu Panda
intendedAudience: Kids movie, but pretty much everyone
rewatchability: Once a month-ish should be okay if wanted, it’s not too long
review: The cast of this movie is so distinguished that there’s almost no one alive who would feel estranged (Jack Black, Angeline Jolie, Jackie Chan, Lucy Liu, Seth Rogen, Dustin Hoffman). And while they all did phenomenally, my two personal favorite characters in this movie were Tai Lung (Ian McShane) and Oogway, both of whom brought their own comedic-but-deep qualities to the film whenever they were involved. Jack Black is always fun to watch, and he carries the movie well, and a generally solid plot and entertaining visuals places this really high by default. The comedy does get taken a bit too far at times, not in the offensive sense, but just a bit annoying at times. The color palette was pretty bland throughout as well, and for an animated film, it definitely could have used a little more lively colors.

title: La La Land
rewatchability: Catchy, good songs, fun dialogue, 2h
review: Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling are like a proper pairing now, huh? They’re pretty solid, to be fair. Mia (Emma Stone) and Sebastian have great chemistry and have pretty relatable career struggles in acting and music respectively. Even though the songs and choreographies are what make this movie a little more poetic than its base content, I think it’s Sebastian’s jazz obsession that was the show-stealer. I wasn’t expecting it at all, and the movie somehow converted me to a jazz purist in the middle there. “Someone in the Crowd” and “A Lovely Night” are probably my favourite songs, but the final sequence with the alternate timeline was probably the most eloquent sequence in the movie - good, mature ending.

title: Legend
intendedAudience: People who like fantasy, have a little time to spare
rewatchability: Whenever, but it doesn’t feel like a ‘movie’ movie in the 21st century way
review: I’m going to confess, I only watched this movie because I love Ferris Bueller’s Day Off, and I heard Sloane (Mia Sara, who I’m kind of in love with) from that was going to be in this. But then I saw Tom Cruise in the cast, and I thought, huh, “why not?” Turns out it’s pretty interesting. 80s movies were just something else. Mia Sara (Lily) and Tom Cruise (Jack) are both really pretty in this one, but there isn’t too much chemistry. It’s not easy to have chemistry with Tom Cruise, so not a big deal. Supporting cast are better than you’d think acting-wise, but VERY campy costumes. The first scene was pretty rightly terrifying and disgusting, if slightly campy, and the villain monologue was pretty impressive. Mia Sara’s introduction was, of course, awesome - a fairy if I ever saw one. Adorable. The costumes and sets have a very Star Wars feel to them, which I’m here for. Highkey the bad guy is the best character in the story. The bad guy’s design is completely awful, but scary, and his voice is AWESOME. His end monologue is great, and the conclusion isn’t bad. Cinematography and particularly the main score was quite good (reminiscent of Leia’s theme in star wars).
spoilerReview: The whole “instant night” thing that happened was pretty unexpected. The random kid, Gump, who woke Jack up was pretty weird, “I know everything”. But the kid’s acting was pretty great. And he almost died of frustration? Whatever, that whole riddle scene was pretty wack. The whole river scene with the weird cannibal witch thing was pretty scary and awesome, so props to Jack for that. Also Jack rejecting the fairy was good. The ballet scene with Mia Sara is actually so well done, too.

title: Les Miserables
rewatchability: Never
review: Yeah, no. It was pretty messed up how such good actors could get pulled into such a long, drawn out movie. Seriously, the cast was so broken (Hugh Jackman, Russel Crowe, Anne Hathaway, Eddie Redmayne, Amanda Seyfried, Helena Bonham Carter, Sacha Baron Cohen). And yet, this was probably the weirdest, most depressing movie I’ve seen from start to finish. Honestly, the Bishop by himself is just a legend, everyone else is hella annoying.

title: Little Women
intendedAudience: I’d imagine it’s an inspirational film for women, but everyone can benefit from this story
rewatchability: 2 hours and then some, so maybe once a year
review: When I started, I wasn’t a fan of Saoirse Ronan. By the end, I’d consider watching anything she was in. Her chemistry with all of the star-studded cast was amazing (Emma Watson, Florence Pugh, Timothee Chalamet, Laura Dern, Meryl Streep), and she carried her character unbelievably credibly. All of the characters’ arcs were satisfying and complemented each other inside the whole story. The artistic talents of the sisters were all refreshing and illustrated their uniqueness and solidarity simultaneously in a form that was pleasing to watch. Of course, the setting allowed for beautiful shots, which completed an original plot with great acting and a meaningful theme.
spoilerReview: RIP Beth :(. She was adorable. Meryl Streep did her stuff, but I’d have liked to see her in more of the plot. The father’s inclusion was pretty ornamental - maybe he should have like… had a conversation. I didn’t really understand Laurie’s (Timothee Chalamet) sudden change of heart to marry Amy, especially because it was completely unwarranted. Meg’s arc with John was pretty solid. The end scene with Jo and the publisher was cool, and Jo’s relationship with Friedrich (Louis Garrel) was good, since we finally got to see her happy.

title: Love and Monsters
rewatchability: Maybe a couple times ever based on quality
review: Yeah, I’m a pretty big Dylan O’Brien fan, so it’s great to see him star in movies like this. Definitely entertaining as ever, popcorn flick if I ever saw one, with just enough heart to keep you in your seat. Joel has chemistry with all the other characters that he interacts with (including a dog and a robot, so that’s impressive). I like the motivation and the whole arc that the movie tries to get across - it’s idealistic but also not cliche and perfect, and it tells you to go take your chances. Solid message. Aimee (Jessica Henwick) is pretty cool, but both Minnow (Ariana Greenblatt) and Clyde (Michael Rooker) have more screentime than her, and are pretty funny. Watching Minnow and Joel interact is great. The ship stuff at the end was okay, and the crab scene was actually pretty cool, if you can suspend your disbelief.

title: Love Letter
intendedAudience: You can probably only best appreciate this when you’re out of school
rewatchability: Winter night, bundled up under a warm blanket
review: I don’t really know what it is about this movie. If you asked me, I don’t think I could give you any one reason that makes it better than Recommendable. And I usually love movies with emotional climaxes, that cut deep and scar you, that make me want to shake the screen. But my heart feels at peace after watching this movie. And better yet, it somehow got me to appreciate the beauty of winter. There were moments in the movie when I could recognize imperfections, but it wasn’t really the perfection of the movie that made it what it was. Its appreciation of the nature of humanity - from Itsuki (girl) stumbling around with her slippers at the beginning, to the classic childhood days that stay with us, to the importance of family, and the beauty of love. This isn’t a love story, certainly, but its really an ode to life and nature. You never know what things you do will make a difference in others’ lives - something as stupid as a doodle, a weird habit, or a song you like can become the reason relationships start or reignite. I didn’t realize that Itsuki (girl) and Hiroko were both played by the same actress (Miho Nakayama), but I guess it really does mean a lot - she’s asking herself to remember Itsuki (boy) who she will and has loved. There’s no aspect of time with this movie. There’s just memory, and I love it. The cinematography is great, the relationships are great, and of course, the mountain scene in the snow is phenomenal acting. Still, for some reason, when the grandfather talked I couldn’t help but feel like there was the weight of the world on his heart.

title: Man of Steel
rewatchability: It’s 2h30 and has a long story, but it’s also quite enjoyable
review: Underrated. If you watched this movie in the cinema, I GUARANTEE you would love it. It’s got the Zack Snyder, Scorsese-esque style and grit, but also has a plot and characters you want to follow. Superman (Henry Cavill) and Lois Lane are wonderfully cast, and have surprisingly great chemistry with each other. The supporting cast of General Zod (Michael Shannon, who’s a little intense here), Jor-El (Russell Crowe), and Perry White (Laurence Fishburne) definitely boosted the star power; I thought Superman’s parents (Diane Lane and Kevin Costner) were probably the best performances too, and they would have got the win if they’d had a little more effect on the plot. Still, this movie tells a new, captivating story that explores themes of loyalty, choice vs fate, conservatism vs trust - it’s not easy. They pull it off remarkably well, and they set up a cinematic universe at the same time. Great job, overall. Fight scenes are also unique because of the direction and colour schemes selected; make them seem a lot more grave and realistic.
spoilerReview: That scene at the end was definitely a clincher. Henry Cavill as farmboy Clark was good, as Superman he was great, but that last scene where he smiled as nerdy Clark? Perfect. Christopher Reeves would have said the same. The last fight against Zod may have gotten a little out of hand, but the climax where Clark yells after killing him is really powerful. The story treats the whole ‘superhero’ concept very seriously and somehow manages to pull it off relatively well, all things considered. The world engine scene and even the destruction of Krypton were super powerful, but my favourite from this movie would be the one where Jonathan Kent dies and Clark’s watching, knowing he could have stopped it. That really sums up his whole struggle, and it’s awesome that they went through with that Uncle Ben-type moment.

title: Meet Joe Black
rewatchability: Once in like half a year might work
review: I did quite like it, even if it was longer than it needed to be. The office scenes were all pretty funny, and the supporting cast were all memorable enough not to be boring. The dynamic between Bill (Anthony Hopkins) and Joe was pretty cool to see, especially since the actors usually do different kinds of movies, and Susan (Claire Forlani) is cool too. The first scene with her meeting Joe is cute, and all of his fish-out-of-water stuff is pretty endearing, even if most of it is just Brad Pitt looking like Brad Pitt. Still, all the peanut butter stuff, “death and taxes” and everything was funny. Final scene with the fireworks was really nice, even if the ending might have been a little confusing for some people.

title: Meet the Robinsons
rewatchability: Whenever you feel stuck
review: I remember watching this as a kid and just thinking about the wide range of emotions that I felt. There’s the wonder of the future, curiosity of the weirder elements, fear at the dystopian visions, elation at the conclusion, and lots of anticipation throughout. Like most movies adapted from books, the plot is just exemplary, and the suspense is held for just long enough for the reveal to be cathartic. The animation itself does a great job of making the future seem awesome (from Lewis’ eyes), and in particular, meeting the Robinsons is so fun. They all seem like such a chaotic group, but if there was ever a way to elicit envy of a family in the future, this is it. So yeah, all the loose ends type up horrendously well, and I just feel really sentimental now. That quote at the end hits really hard - Walt Disney is the man.
spoilerReview: Young Goob was hilarious, and I didn’t actually think he would become a supervillain (even after having watched this in the past) because that’s just how most kids are now. Scary. Future Goob was a little creepy, but his arc was great, and even DORIS was a decent antagonist, all things considered. Anyway, Mildred (orphan house lady) gets MVP for best pep talk ever, but honestly all the adults in this movie are just insanely supportive. Wilbur and Lewis’ relationship is cool, and I just LOVE the time machine designs. Franny is adorable as both a kid and adult, and older Cornelius is just so relieving to watch (Tom Selleck is cool, and the joke was pretty on point too).

title: Moon
rewatchability: Probably wouldn’t, it’s 1h30 and pretty reveal-centric
review: I do have to say, this movie was a lot better than I thought at first. It started pretty slow, and I thought it was really boring, but as soon as the plot started, it was hard not to be interested. The main reveal and the interactions between the main characters were definitely something to watch. Sam Rockwell is a better actor than I thought before, and Kevin Spacey does an okay job with Gertie (who was pretty cool). Plot was good, if a little ambiguous, and the pacing was probably the best thing about the movie. The cautionary message about the potential of future technology is also well put, and I think the movie did well to find as much heart as it did.
spoilerReview: This movie was BUILT on spoilers. So obviously the first big reveal was that the guy he saved was also him - there were a few ways to go from there, but it was easy to be interested already. Then the realization that they were clones, along with the pretty real reactions from both of them. The idea that the Tess (Dominique McElligott) and Eve (Kaya Scodelario) messages were actually from the past was heartbreaking to watch when Sam talks to older Eve, so that was well done. It’s also refreshing to see that the computers aren’t the villains for once - Gertie can take a bow. Then the idea that there were tons of clones there was also pretty scary, and I feel like the ending was the best way to handle the situation and characters respectfully.

title: Mr. and Mrs. Smith
rewatchability: Pretty much whenever, it’s kinda a popcorn flick
review: There’s not a lot wrong with this movie; between Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, there’s something in it for everyone. It’s pretty good as an action movie, and the romance is bearable. Eddie’s character is a typical Vince Vaughn comedic relief, and he does his job to perfection. The tech is cool, the cars are cool, the chemistry is there. There’s enough humor in there to keep you entertained, and is a decent enough popcorn flick for anyone that just wants a movie to kill some time once in a while.

title: Mulan
rewatchability: 1h30, but quite fast paced
review: LETS GET DOWN TO BUSINESS. That song will never not be awesome. Overall, this movie’s pacing - and most Disney classic movies’ pacing - is probably what makes them so great. There’s always something happening, and there’s great comedy in between important plot points. Grandma Fa (June Foray) was hilarious in every single line she spoke, and Mushu was a blessing. Take the win. Mulan’s parents weren’t outlandishly traditional or anything, and their reactions to everything were fairly believable. The villain was a little cartoonish, but it kinda is a cartoon, and the huns were so broken in terms of military strength that it might have been hard for people to look past that. Shang was cool too, and apart from his great song, Reflection was really important in terms of driving the plot.
spoilerReview: Ah, Disney. 2D animation can be really powerful, and that scene with the reflection really pulled through. Also when she took her dad’s armor to go to war… that was great. Mushu’s whole secret guardian plot was pretty smart, and the ancestors were all quite funny also. It was good to see that the emperor was forward-thinking, even if that seems a little idealistic. Still great.

title: Mulan
rewatchability: Maybe once or twice ever
review: So this movie was really hard to classify, especially given that I have a lot of exposure to the original. Still, it wasn’t really an action movie, but it wasn’t comedy either. It felt most like a war movie in the middle, and there was definitely an element of hollywood magic when it came to the relationship between Mulan and Xianniang (Gong Li, who does a great job here). The ensemble cast for this movie was really impressive: Jet Li, Donnie Yen, Tzi Ma. Overall, it wasn’t bad by any means, it just wasn’t as consistently engaging as one would have expected from a disney movie plot. That said, it’s important to recognize that they emphasized the reality of the movie’s themes, at the expense of iconic characters and songs, which may leave a bad taste in some of our mouths. Still, the movie had heart, and even if it wasn’t the most watchable, it didn’t underperform drastically at any point. Yifei is also incredibly cute whenever she smiles, so take that as you will.

title: Murder Mystery
rewatchability: Whenever, it’s an Adam Sandler rom-com
review: Have some time on your hands? Want a couple laughs? 1.5 hours is a fair trade off for this movie. A cast of Adam Sandler, Jennifer Aniston, Luke Evans, Gemma Arterton (etc.) make it pretty entertaining throughout. And although the movie’s structure mocks that of classic murder mysteries, it does suffer (ironically) from some of the same cliches. But the chemistry between Aniston and Sandler, and the abundance of non-forced funny moments more than makes up for any kind of unoriginality in the plot. Sandler’s moustache does kind of piss me off though.

title: My Neighbour Totoro
rewatchability: Once in a couple months
review: Definitely one of the most peaceful movies I’ve seen, and it’s got all the standard Shinto charm and weirdness. Music is calming and the scenery in this movie is especially nice. I know it has a lot of symbolism for Japanese people, but it’s not a bad watch. The sister dynamic between Satsuki and Mei (Chika Sakamoto) is pretty cute and makes up most of the movie. Takamoto and the Cat Bus are pretty cool but also the Cat Bus scares the hell out of me and Takamoto looks pretty weird. Also the ‘plot’ of the whole movie is a little meh, since it’s just them chilling for most of it. Still, it’s a pretty accurate representation of a challenging coming-of-age (you know, minus all the kami).

title: Ocean’s Eight
intendedAudience: Pretty much everyone, but it’s a heist film, so people who like that
rewatchability: Only 1
review: So I watched this after Ocean’s 11,12, and 13, and I didn’t expect it to live up to the others (which I did like), but it was actually really watchable. The casting in particular was great - Sandra Bullock and Cate Blanchett have great chemistry, Anna Hathaway is great, there’s lots of diversity in Mindy Kalling and Awkwafina (both of whom acted the best I’ve seen from them). Helena Bonham Carter, Sarah Paulson, and Rihanna were all funny and the plot itself wasn’t half bad. It didn’t feel like a deliberately “girl-power” movie either, and it was great to see an ensemble cast of just women (and James Corden). Definitely worth a rewatch.

title: Once Upon a Time in Hollywood
intendedAudience: Definitely for adults, or film buffs in particular
rewatchability: Prob wouldn’t
review:
I have literally no idea what this movie was about. I don’t know if it’s just me being stupid, or Tarantino’s weird style, but the plot made pretty much no sense to me. Stuff kinda just happened. Stylistically, the period-piece/60s style kinda slapped, and the cast was loaded (Leo Di Caprio, Brad Pitt, Margot Robbie, Al Pacino). The chemistry between Leo and Brad was pretty good, but Margot’s plot was pretty much just there and totally unrelated.

LOTS of blood, typical Tarantino. Lots of swearing too.

title: Paper Towns
intendedAudience: High schoolers about to graduate, adults thinking back to their younger days
rewatchability: Could do once in a couple years, but it’s mostly for young people
review: I really like how wholesome this one is. Honestly not surprised that it was based on a John Green novel. Quentin is relatable in a natural, authentic sense, and Margo (Cara Delevingne) is a manic-pixie-dream-girl, but it’s okay because the message of the movie is that no one is actually as one dimensional as they are in the minds of others. The real heart of this movie is Quentin’s pining for Margo, his chemistry with Radar (Justice Smith) and Ben (Austin Abrams), and the upbeat tone and shenanigans that they actually get up to while trying to find Margo. Lacey (Halston Sage) was cool too, and did shake up the whole standard clique-bashing in these kinds of movies. I watched this soon after high school, so it did hit me in the feels quite a bit, but I think the authenticity of this movie will get through to anyone who watches. Might be fun to watch with friends before you graduate.
spoilerReview: The comedy in this one is also outstanding. Ben’s entire character is hilarious; his banter with Radar, peeing in the car, dodging the cow. Singing the pokemon theme was probably the best scene for me because it just seemed so real and fun - and obviously I can relate. The ending scene wasn’t the perfecting ending Quentin wanted, but I think it might have struck home a little harder with some better delivery from Margo - Delevingne did a great job in the first part of the movie, though. The outro scenes were satisfying, and it was generally the bittersweet ending I’d come to expect from such a movie, but it’s good to see that Quentin grows over the course of the plot.

title: Parasite
rewatchability: 2h20, but has a good mix of enjoyable and serious parts
review: I swear this movie was marketed wrong. I would have seen it so much earlier if the posters didn’t look like every other horror movie ever - which it really isn’t. I’m not typically a dark, grimy realism movie kinda guy, but Bong Joonho definitely knew what he was doing (and has the bag to show for it). I can’t guarantee that everyone will like it, but I can assure you that you won’t be bored watching… one way or another. The plot, the sets, the dialogue, the characters all scream for your attention continuously, and the pacing keeps the suspense real until the very end. The cast is extremely versatile, from the expressive Mrs Park (Cho Yeojeong, who’s just beautiful) and classist Mr. Park (Lee Sungyun), to Ki-Jung - who’s just the funniest and most likeable - to the crafty Mr. Kim (Song Kangho), the loud Mrs. Kim (Jang Hyejin), and the relatable Ki-Woo (Choi Woosik). The supporting cast of Dahye (Jeong Jiso) and Dasong (Jeong Hyunjoong) as comedic sides and Moongwang (Lee Jeongeun) with Geunse (Park Myunghoon) as dramatic sides worked really well to keep the balance as well. The gritty tone somehow managed to persist through the comedic moments, and there was always a sense of mystery that kept me interested.
spoilerReview: I have to say: that one scene with Ki-Jung smoking over the toilet during the flood? Cinematic gold. What a gangster. Anyway, the movie held together the tension pretty well throughout, with the third act basically just ending like a Shakespearean tragedy (with a little promise at the end). So yeah, that house was awesome. Shots were wonderful. Acting was great. The scene with them all drinking in the living room is also one of my favourites (Ki-Jung is hilarious). There’s an authentic family feeling to the characters, even with all the crazy things they go through. Ki-Jung’s death didn’t really hit as hard as I would’ve hoped, but the morse code thing and the smell motifs were both utilized to good effect.

title: Percy Jackson and the Olympians: The Lightning Thief
rewatchability: It’s not AMAZING, so you can rewatch at will without losing too much quality
review: In this movie’s defence, it’s not half as bad as everyone makes it out to be. Personally, I don’t have a big problem with the casting of Annabeth, especially considering Alexandra Daddario is super attractive anyway, and has pretty solid chemistry with Logan Lerman’s Percy Jackson. The standout scenes from this movie would probably be the capture the flag fight at camp, and then the Vegas Poker Face montage. Brandon T. Jackson was pretty funny in what was an otherwise more expository type of movie, with even super talented cast members (Sean Bean, Pierce Brosnan) being underwhelming. Rosario Dawson’s Persephone was pretty random, but it was funny nonetheless. The villains in this movie were the main issue, with Luke being pretty much a million times worse as a villain than as a hero. Seemed like the movie might have been able to benefit from a little more budget, but it was still rewatchable if only for the nostalgia of Riordan’s books.

title: Perks of Being a Wallflower
rewatchability: Definitely first time when you’re in high school/college, and once a year after maybe
review: This is definitely a tragic movie, but it’s got MAD heart. And if you’re a silent, introverted type, you probably will feel a little emotional kick from it (but really like nobody can get through to you, so I’m not promising anything). If you’re an extrovert who pretends to be an introvert, well this is probably your fav movie (that’s also how you check for these people btw). Logan Lerman’s Charlie and Emma Watson’s Sam are really cute (and it’s like Percy Jackson and Hermione Granger chilling together), not to mention Ezra Miller’s hella chill Patrick (He’s basically the Flash too, so this is like the Young Fiction Avengers). The music is cool, and just edgy enough to match the audience, and the subject matter is pretty serious. Overall, it’s definitely not UPLIFTING, but it puts you in a place that makes you feel a little more complete than when you started. Nina Dobrev and Paul Rudd are a pretty solid supporting cast too.

title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End
rewatchability: Once a month is possible, it’s just great
review: I don’t know why exactly people don’t like this one so much - it might be too outlandish for some, I guess - but I definitely thought it was one of the most awesome movies I’d ever seen when I first watched it. Depp’s Captain Jack is still awesome, supported by a great cast of Lord Beckett (Tom Hollander), Davy Jones (Bill Nighy), Captain Barbossa (Geoffrey Rush), Will Turner (Orlando Bloom), and Elizabeth Swann (Keira Knightley). Then the supporting characters like Gibbs (Kevin McNally), Tia Dalma (Naomie Harris), Pintel and Ragetti, Mullroy and Murtogg, Bootstrap Bill (Stellan Skarsgard), and James Norrington (Jack Davenport) are also iconic. The introduction of Singapore and Sao Feng’s (Chow Yunfat) crew was really cool leading up to the Brethren Court, which I just wholly enjoyed. Action was great, all the plotting was awesome, the characters were all handled really well, especially given the cliffhanger from the last movie, and it’s always a thrill to watch.
spoilerReview: Elizabeth’s speech and the whole final battle was to die for. I will say I would have liked a little less Calypso stuff, but it was good character building for Davy Jones. Also Keith Richards as Jack’s dad was hilarious, since he was the inspiration for Depp’s mannerisms. But yeah, Barbossa was almost as wonderful as Jack, their dialogue is actually really meaningful, and the resolution to the arc was all pretty good - it made us like Will more than we would have otherwise. Beckett was a really annoying person, but we love to hate him, even when he’s bullying Davy Jones. Elizabeth is also just a badass in this one. Oh, also, the whole song stuff is really cool mood-building, but the Locker scene with the hallucinations and crabs was weird.

title: Pitch Perfect
rewatchability: Very poppy and has funny scenes
review: So this is where the cup song is from. In middle school it was a really big thing, and I thought my classmates were really just great at percussion, but this makes more sense. So Beca here is cool, since Anna Kendrick refuses to ever play a character awkwardly. There’s a quirky mix of characters with Fat Amy (Rebel Wilson), Jesse (Skylar Astin), etc. before quirky became obnoxious. The riff-off scene is iconic, and the song choices are pretty cool for me since early 2010s pop is really my default genre of music. The romance between Beca and Jesse is okay - a little underdeveloped - but the camaraderie within the Bellas is much more prominent and central to the story. It follows the romcom template, except instead of a guy, Beca has relationship issues with her friends. That’s basically it. And the last song medley is quite great too.

title: Pride & Prejudice
rewatchability: 2h, pretty dramatic, good to vaguely know the plot
review: So yeah, the music was nice. The scenery was definitely cool. Elizabeth and Darcy (Matthew Macfayden) have some pretty emotional scenes, and Mr. Bennet (Donald Sutherland) and Lady Catherine (Judy Dench) gave some really good performances, for sure. This movie is basically a soap opera, with all the emphasis on marriage and status, even though Elizabeth has some pretty mold-breaking dialogue. A lot of the story is irrelevant to the main plot, and many characters’ arcs aren’t utilized to their full potential. Also, I’m just not really into this kind of movie, I guess. It does really seem like a “feel-good” kind of romance movie, with some Shakespearean influence, and even though I haven’t read the novel by Jane Austen, I believe that the norm is true here: the book is truly better than the movie.

title: Ratatouille
rewatchability: It’s 1h50, but the story is cool, and extremely rewatchable
review: Gotta love this one. I will admit, there’s a little bias here because I’ve seen it so much in the past, but it really is a great movie. It’s kinda like ‘How to train your dragon’, except it’s more grounded in reality yet more experimental with its characters (but a little less compelling in terms of storytelling). Linguini (Lou Romano) and Remy have a hilarious symbiotic relationship that goes against not only everything the world and their families/friends are saying, but the natural order of biology (and possibility, but it’s Pixar). The simple message here is “Anyone can cook”, and it’s said countless times in the story - this really is a stand-in for “don’t judge a book by its cover”, which is more general (albeit overused). The music, the visuals, the plot, the supporting cast of Colette (Janeane Garofalo), Gusteau (Brad Garett), Ego (Peter O’Toole), and Skinner (Ian Holm) all help make the movie a compelling and lasting story, centered around its worthwhile moral.
spoilerReview: I didn’t understand a lot of what happened with the second act of the movie when I was younger, including the scene where Linguini is hungover, so there’s that to consider. Shoutout to Emile (Peter Sohn) and Remy’s dad (Brian Dehenny) for coming in clutch at the end. Also the plotline with Remy helping his rat-bros when he becomes famous is seriously underrated and is definitely something that really happens in life. Ego’s epiphany scene was pretty awesome too, and his entire character until then was SUPER menacing.

title: Raya and the Last Dragon
rewatchability: 1h35, and decently entertaining
review: The south-east-asian influence was quite strong with this one. Naming the 5 lands after parts of the dragon is cool, and honestly just including dragons is always a plus. The idea that they incorporated the ASIAN dragon (water-centric, more snake-like and long) is definitely really cool. Raya (Kelly Marie Tran) is definitely a likeable protagonist, and the initial scene does a great job of introducing her, her father (Daniel Dae Kim), and the cutest ever baby armadillo-looking-thing Tuk Tuk (Alan Tudyk). Big props to the animators for that. I’m usually not too into Awkwafina’s humour, but her quips are pretty funny coupled with Raya’s more badass personality. Then there’s Namari (Gemma Chan, who’s beautiful) who does have good chemistry with Raya - their little slang that the creators made up (binturi, dep la, etc.) was really cool and brought a new level to their dynamic, especially since they’re based on real languages. The supporting cast of Raya’s friends are pretty funny too, but the visuals and the music do some REALLY heavy lifting, especially near the end, and got me in the feels. That’s what gets this movie this high. They really capture the right tone in the climax, and their command over emotion is definitely really impactful. Good show all around.

title: Ready Player One
intendedAudience: Anyone who plays video games, kids and teens
rewatchability: It’s 2h20, and I physically couldn’t finish it in one sitting, but it’s a good watch, for sure
review: Yeah, definitely worth it. Spielberg things, you know? I actually didn’t until I’d finished, but it made sense. I feel like as a part of the target audience, it was a really interesting watch, and a lot of thought was put into the world and characters (of course, it’s from a book). So the plot was pretty sound. Parzival/Wade (Tye Sheridan) was an okay protagonist, and his motivation was really the best thing about him - he was a fan. That, and his camaraderie with his gamer friends - especially Artemis - gave the movie a lot of heart. The ways that they solved the challenges were cool, and cameos from Simon Pegg as Ogden, Hannah John-Kamen as F’Nale and Mark Rylance as Halliday helped give the movie a solid acting backbone. My personal favorite was Artemis - she was a real strong female character without any of the cliches that are usually attached to that mold. Overall, this movie is basically nerd paradise - making pop-culture the center of the universe is the dream. It’s got a lot of emotion and is enjoyable, and made well. The pacing is a little questionable, and it feels really long to sit through, which might make rewatching an issue. TJ Miller as i-R0k was honestly hilarious too, and he’s almost deserving of the win.
spoilerReview: So Nolan Sorrento (Ben Mendelsohn) and IOI weren’t awful villains - they were the antithesis to what the gamers stood for. Makes sense. His final hesitant moment at the end, and his persistent tentativeness to get his hands dirty, made him believable as just a corporate money-seeker. F’Nale - I swear I never heard her name in the movie - was cool too, even if it was kinda sad to see her get OHKOed at the end. The Samantha birthmark thing was cool, and Wade’s aunt and uncle did die, so there are a few loose ends that were kinda glossed over. H (Lena Waithe) as a big dude was pretty funny too.

title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes
rewatchability: It’s 1h45, weirdly paced
review: Pretty solid. Caesar is awesome. James Franco does a pretty great job as Will, and Caroline (Freida Pinto), Charles (John Litgow), and Dodge (Tom Felton) are a decent supporting cast. All the apes scenes were the highlights; I think Serkis needs big props for his performance. The motion capture and effects were all wonderful. It did get a little slow in the middle, but the message about the dangers of genetic modification is pretty relevant, and I think it was a good plot point. I felt like Charles’ arc didn’t need so much screentime, but you should definitely watch for the apes.

title: Rush Hour
intendedAudience: There’s a lot of non-PC offense to be found here for those looking for it, so you have to be able to look past that
rewatchability: Constantly
review: HILARIOUS. Whoever thought of putting Chris Tucker and Jackie Chan in a movie together is a certified legend. Everything about this movie SENDS. The 90s references, the physical comedy, the ostentatious dialogue, the music, it was all beyond hilarious. It makes fun of both Asian and American culture in equal measure, and the chemistry it finds is just great. It has action, it has comedy, it’s probably the ultimate popcorn flick.
spoilerReview: Of course, Thomas being Juntao was a big ouch for Han, and he wasn’t a BAD villain, but the movie was obviously dominated by the underdog protagonists. The airport scene always has me rolling on the floor. And the last scene at the gate with the FBI guys? Quoted that for YEARS.

title: Rush Hour 2
rewatchability: You could watch once a week
review: Although this one doesn’t hold the same comedic significance in my heart as the first, it’s definitely nothing to scoff at. Funny as hell, Tucker and Jackie Chan combine again for an extremely amusing sequel, complete with more great music, fighting, and cultural adjustment. Hu Li (Zhang Ziyi) and Isabella (Roselyn Sanchez) provide good diversity in the cast, but the refined focus on the villains and the jumpy setting takes away from the magic of Lee and Carter. Still, their interactions are as golden as ever, and this is a popcorn flick if there ever was one.

title: Say Anything…
intendedAudience: Probably young adults who like romance movies
rewatchability: 1h40, and is very comforting, but wouldn’t rewatch exactly
review: So this is the movie with the boombox outside the window. Not gonna lie, I was originally only watching for that scene, but it’s not even played up so much here. Still iconic though. This is a weird romance movie because it pretty much doesn’t have any of the classic tropes that we’re used to - it’s a regular guy and girl just hanging out for most of the movie. Lloyd and Diane Court (Ione Sky, awesome name, really cute) have really cute chemistry, and the writers manage to make the dialogue very conversable - you wouldn’t feel weird saying it to a friend. I think the subplot with Diane’s dad (John Mahoney) was pretty auxiliary, and Lloyd’s friends were really funny. So yeah, good movie to watch once - it’s comforting and subverts your romance expectations in a wholesome way.

title: Scent of a Woman
intendedAudience: Adults, wouldn’t be bad in groups
rewatchability: Enjoyable, but 2h30 and emotional so once a year maybe
review: And the Academy Award goes to… was there ever any question? Al Pacino is just that guy. His chemistry with Charlie (Chris O’Donell), who’s a great main character in his own right, is awesome to follow throughout the story. His atmosphere, the “Hoo-Ah” humming, his dialogue delivery, his performance as a blind man… all on top. The moral lesson about integrity and believing in yourself is great, and there’s some really iconic scenes here. The supporting cast of Donna (Gabrielle Anwar, who’s gorgeous) and Frank’s family all help build his overall characterization, and the final speech as well as the last scene in New York are all-timers.

title: Seventh Son
rewatchability: 1h45, but effects are cool
review: Tom and Alice’s (Alicia Vikader) scenes together made up almost all of the good moments here, and I could rarely be asked to care about the plot. Kit Harrington’s cameo was cool, but I really couldn’t understand what Spook (Jeff Bridges) was saying throughout the whole movie. The effects were cool, with all the witches turning into massive birds, and Julianne Moore was okay as the antagonist, too.

title: She’s the Man
rewatchability: Once in a couple months
review: Pretty fun, overall, but also pretty weird. The movie quality wasn’t all that impressive, and Bynes came on a bit hard at the beginning, but her portrayal of a boy was pretty funny, and the juxtaposition with Viola’s character was definitely a good contrast. There was a lot of good comedy, and Channing Tatum had decent chemistry with Bynes. The moral of girls being able to do anything guys can was probably progressive for the time, but is rather commonplace nowadays - regardless, it is meaningful, even if it ended up being a love story.

title: Shrek 2
rewatchability: It’s 1h45, but pretty engaging throughout
review: This movie is like the Pokemon Gold of animation. It’s better than the first in that it tones down its brashness while maintaining everything that made the first so original and iconic - the music, the satirical cliche-calling, and the heart. In particular, the characters in this movie were just outstanding. Shrek (Mike Myers), Fiona (Cameron Diaz), and Donkey (Eddie Murphy, who’s hilarious) are the mainstays, but The Fairy Godmother (Jennifer Saunders) was so entertaining that I almost gave her the win. Throw in notable character arcs for the King (John Cleese) and Puss in Boots (best character, SO funny) and a host of little fairy tale references, and you definitely have a fun experience. Also apparently Julie Andrews is the Queen, so yay. But yeah, everything is great. Still a little annoying, but that’s definitely intentional.

title: Silver Linings Playbook
rewatchability: Once in a couple years, it’s pretty emotional
review: 2012 was probably Jennifer Lawrence’s prime, and even though I was a fan of her as a person, I never really understood why people considered her such a good actor - until I saw this movie. Not gonna lie, Tiffany is easily one of my favourite characters in recent memory, and JLaw’s performance is definitely winning and hella attractive. Bradley Cooper and Robert Deniro fill out the rest of the heavy hitters, and Chris Tucker and Anupam Kher are comic relief (which is fine, I guess). The chemistry between Pat (Bradley Cooper) and Tiffany is great, even if they don’t know it to start with, and it carries the movie. Deniro is obviously a good actor, but most of his arc was just the most annoying thing ever.

title: Slumdog Millionaire
rewatchability: It’s super story-based, so probably only once
review: Man, the acting in this one was definitely something. Even the child actors seemed to pile on the emotions. As adults, Latika (Freida Pinto) and Salim (Madhur Mittal) both did great as well, but their screen time was so limited that it wasn’t comparable to Patel. Anil Kapoor and Irrfan Khan did decent jobs as veteran actors in their respective roles too, considering they were effectively acting in a second language. The story itself is really great, and keeps the suspense building in a way that keeps the drama, fulfills some happiness for the audience and characters, but doesn’t break the “realism” that’s been established as the USP of this movie. Of course, Jamal, Salim, and Latika’s stories as orphans or “slumdogs” and their suffering might be portrayed in a manner that might seem completely unimaginable and detached from most western viewers, but such a story is seldom out of the public eye in developing countries - it’s good to see that they’re being recognized and elevated to a larger global audience.
spoilerReview: The whole movie is pretty much spoilers, isn’t it? Pretty much every scene from Jamal’s childhood pays off during the game-show, and all the adult scenes are a part of the short arc in the present. My favourite was probably the whole ‘3 Musketeers’ motif that was going on - made the last scene super powerful. But also Jamal having the brain to realize that Prem, the host, was lying to him was definitely a power move (because a liar definitely knows a liar). But yeah, I like how Jamal never gives up on Latika. On paper, Salim’s character is so complex and messed up that it would be the best, but I don’t know how I’d feel about him if I was Jamal. Then again, that ending scene was pretty cool. And Jai Ho is nice.

title: Snowden
rewatchability: Wouldn’t, it’s a one-off and 2h15
review: So yeah I now have massive respect for this guy Edward Snowden. The movie’s basically a dramatic documentary, so there’s no real spoilers, but I felt like when they showed him at the end it was even better than seeing someone play him. Otherwise, Lindsay Mills (Shailene Woodley) was definitely a breath of fresh air in front of his dark and brooding lifestyle. The supporting cast was actually quite good: Corbin O’Brien (Rhys Ifans) was intimidating and cool, Glenn Greenwald (Zachary Quinto) was reassuring, Ewen MacAskil (Tom Wilkinson) and Laura Poitras (Melissa Leo) definitely showed off the best of journalism. But yeah more than the movie itself, which was cool (if a little slow), I just find it really impressive that someone actually did what Snowden did. Definitely an inspiration to the rest of the tech-types.

title: Soul
rewatchability: It’s 1h45, and not as smooth as you’d like, so maybe only a few times ever
review: So yeah, I guess it’s pretty interesting. The whole ‘soul’ premise is obviously vastly derivative from monotheist religions, and the whole ‘personality assignment’ does undermine individual accountability, even if it is a fun scene to watch. I particularly liked the fact that a bunch of really famous people were 22’s mentors. Joe (Jamie Foxx) was a decent lead, and his infatuation with jazz music was pretty well displayed. I guess I’m a little older than the target demographic for this movie, so it doesn’t really resonate as purely with me as it might with someone a little more impressionable.

title: Spencer
intendedAudience: Adults, people who have lives that are too structured
rewatchability: Maybe once more when I’m an adult
review: Never thought I’d write that name in the winner’s column, but here we are. Kristen Stewart acts in this movie almost completely alone, and she’s actually phenomenal. She’s always been beautiful, but as an incarnation of everyone’s beloved Princess Diana, she gains the dignity and purity that will make anyone sympathetic to her struggles. Knowing that something similar to this happened in real life is only that much more impactful, and she pulls off the tragic helplessness brilliantly. The direction is actually amazing too - I usually like bright colours in a movie, but the filter that they put on the camera really fits the royal palette. The costumes are great, especially the one with the veil. Of course, the subject matter can be really really heavy, which is part of what makes this movie so important, but you also can’t rewatch too often. The bulimia scenes and the mass eating were both heartbreaking. The scenes with Diana and the kids are particularly endearing, and Maggie (Sally Hawkins) is a welcome surprise in the third act. The Anne Boleyn comparisons are interesting, but went a little over my head. Jack Farthing’s Charles is just so annoying, which means he’s probably about right. The end scene is really nice to watch, and I love how at peace she is - saying Spencer and taking back whatever ground she can is definitely really meaningful. I quite liked the movie, even if it made me pretty sad.

title: Spider-Man: Far From Home
rewatchability: 2h, and pretty big twists, so once in a year
review: Just rewatched, and surprisingly enough, it’s pretty much the same as I remember it. Holland was great as Peter once again, obviously, and both Happy (Jon Favreau) and Aunt May (Marisa Tomei) were great as supporting cast. Betty (Angourie Rice) and Ned (Jacob Batalon) were cute, Nick Fury (Sam Jackson) and Maria Hill (Cobie Smulders) were fun too. MJ (Zendaya) wasn’t actually as iconic as in Homecoming, and she seemed a little too uncomfortable. The theme was great, and the plot was fine, but I felt like there was a little left to be desired from the story even though it ticked most of the right boxes—maybe I was looking for the same kind of heart that was in the first movie. Jake Gyllenhaal wasn’t bad either, but Tom Holland (and EDITH) really did have to carry this movie.
spoilerReview: So Beck’s a villain. Pretty much everyone figured that, and I think even though it was obvious, his hero scenes were so much better than his villain scenes that I guess we kinda wished that he was a real hero. Then the business with Fury and Hill being Skrulls is cool but a little confusing, given that we don’t really know what they’re trying to do with that. Anyway, Iron Man’s shadow doesn’t just still rest over the MCU universe, but even their actual films, and I feel like he was the center of the story without even having been there. Not exactly ideal for the future of the universe. But again, Holland was cool. J Jonah Jameson’s cameo was awesome, and the cliffhanger was great.

title: Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
intendedAudience: Literally however, it’s fun either way
rewatchability: Depends on preference
review:
As a sequel, there’s basically nothing more you could ask for out of this. Following up Into the Spider-Verse was always gonna be a herculean task, and this sequel had a pretty good handle on what people loved about the original. A lot of the appeal of ITSV was that it looked and sounded incredible, and ATSV just casually one-upped maybe the most groundbreaking animated movie since Toy Story. The character progression is seamless too—Miles (Shameik Moore) is more confident and assertive, Gwen (Hailee Steinfeld) is given some much-needed depth and vulnerability, and the first ten minutes where she’s introduced are pretty much perfect.

The biggest issue holding the movie back is probably the pacing; the overload of random fluff and joke breaks is a far cry from the tight economy of runtime in the original. It sets up a bunch of stakes and conflicts and doesn’t really give any of them room to breathe because there’s so much being introduced. Gonna have to reserve more complete judgment until the next one is out, but as it stands, it feels like despite running (in gorgeously exhilarating fashion) over two hours, this movie doesn’t seem to really get anywhere.

title: Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
rewatchability: Max twice a year
review: Not gonna lie, didn’t expect this to be any good at all - didn’t even bother watching it in the cinema. BIGGEST RIP EVER. Movie smashed everything ever. Miles is a protagonist that you want to root for and be friends with and BE (period). Completely relatable, and still comes off as original. Movie itself is beautiful, and they use the fact that it’s animated to their full advantage - lots of frames look like they’ve been taken straight from the comics. Worth watching purely for the visuals. Soundtrack slapped, but more on that below. Suffice to say, this movie ended the debate about who the best spiderman is - and it’s none of the ones that were considered before (sorry Tom Holland, ur cool). Regardless, LOTS of heart, and one for the ages. Only thing that would be cautioned is not to rewatch too frequently, or the emotional impact loses its value.
spoilerReview: I don’t think there’s a single character in the movie that wasn’t phenomenal. Villains killed it - Doc Ock was set up wonderfully and was a great variation from the Spiderman 2 “Octavius” dude. Kingpin was intimidating af, and Prowler managed to be believable as both an uncle and an assassin - his death was sad, but it was a great moment for both Miles’ and his dad’s development, and their relationship. ALL THE SPIDERMEN were iconic AF (exception being the pig, that one falls a little flat). Gwen and Miles had INSANE chemistry in every scene, and both Blonde and Fat Peter were standouts in their own ways. Weirdo spidermen did their job, and the third act did the movie justice. Scene with Miles jumping off the building in the night with music was the best scene, and that’s that.

title: Spider-Man: No Way Home
rewatchability: Depends on preference
review: Probably for the best that I got to writing this after the hype died down. First thing is that this movie is a LOT of fun in theaters, and at its best is genuinely magical to watch. Wraps up the Tom Holland trilogy reasonably well, but what holds it back (as with the other movies) is that it feels like it needs to take one step back for every two steps forward in Peter’s (Holland’s) arc, retreading points in his development out of fear of audience backlash. Supporting cast is great as always—Marisa Tomei really gets the chance to shine here as Aunt May, even if Ned (Jacob Batalon) and MJ (Zendaya) get a little sidelined to make way for all the MCU newcomers. In trying to be a perfect conclusion, No Way Home sometimes forgets to be a movie with any sort of meaning behind it—as in Endgame, the jokes, callbacks, and “now clap” moments tend to stifle the actual tension and emotion in the film’s own story. It’s great to see for the first time, but it just doesn’t have the kind of staying power that I’d hoped for.

title: Spirited Away
intendedAudience: This will scare the life out of little kids, so definitely like 15+
rewatchability: This is one of those once in a lifetime movies, so rewatch with a gap of like 4+ years
review: Straight up, this movie is creepy, but it’s beautiful. You have to watch it alone and without anticipation to get the full feel of it, but the story is really cool to watch. The setting and characters are super super weird, sometimes even scary, but I think that’s the point of the film—to explain that not everything around you is as bad as it looks, and that you shouldn’t judge entirely based on what you see. The relationship between Haku and Chiriho (Rumi Hiiragi) is really cute, and Lin (Yumi Tamai) is a pretty good complement to Chiriho too. And as great as the story is, the animation and the music of this movie are just in another world. First, every one of Haku’s scenes is wonderful cuz the guy just looks awesome. The setting and buildup are all great too, animation-wise. But THE MUSIC. The main piano theme for this movie is the BEST PIANO I have heard in my entire life. So if anything, just listen to that. But overall, this is definitely great. Won the Oscar for best animated movie, so there’s that too.
spoilerReview: Haku looks awesome as it is, but DRAGON-HAKU? DUDE. Man is awesome. The twin grannys were creepy as hell, but also it was good to see them being brought down to their level by Chiriho. No Face was cool, if a little weird and unusual. The Baby was just weird. AND THE PARENTS. Chiriho’s parents are literally the worst parents in the world. That is all. But you will love this movie.

title: Superman
intendedAudience: People who like retro movies, people who like superhero movies
rewatchability: It’s a classic, but 2h30
review: There’s no word for this movie other than classic. The theme itself is just breathtaking, and Christopher Reeve was perfect as Superman. His interactions with Lois Lane were great (and a little hilarious) and the tone of the movie fit his character a lot. Marlon Brando as Jor-El and Jene Hackman as Lex Luthor were decent cameos, even if Lex was a little more comical than I would have expected, because of his henchmen. The pacing of the plot was pretty offputting, but they did explain Clark’s origin in the most complete way, so new watchers won’t miss out. The last act is pretty interesting too, and helps redeem the plot from being too stagnant. So yeah, watch for the music and nostalgia.
spoilerReview: Bro Lois is actually so thirsty in this, it’s so funny. Also how come Marlon Brando can’t pronounce Krypton? It’s pretty funny that nobody told him how it’s meant to be said. Anyway, yeah, that ending was pretty wild, huh? Nobody ever uses time travel so casually any more. But this guy was just like “nah it’s cool” and reversed time. Hilarious. Also the first scene with the floating diamond prison for Zod and co. didn’t age well, but I like how they set up their villains for the sequel already.

title: Sword in the Stone
rewatchability: Multiple times a day, if you want
review: So yeah, this was just a really cute movie. 1963, and the 2D animation really really holds up, all things considered. The main spoiler for this movie is really pop culture by this point, but it has very little to do with the plot, and the movie focuses on preaching a pro-education message for their target audience. The scenes with the animal transformations are cool, and the squirrel scenes were especially funny - I had to give that crying squirrel the win, come on. That was precious. But yeah, Merlin (Karl Swenson) and Archimedes (Junius Matthews) had really funny banter throughout, and Arthur (Rickie Sorensen) was the perfect wide-eyed representative of the audience. Overall, it does have the antique disney feel, even if they couldn’t resist a few quirks with Merlin’s powers. Luckily for parents, there’s enough there for you to laugh about with your kids.

title: Ta Ra Rum Pum
rewatchability: It’s 2h30, but lots of action, songs, etc
review: Obviously I’m extremely biased with this one, because it’s one of my childhood movies. I grew up on this one. RV (Saif Ali Khan) and Radhika (Rani Mukherji) go from being confused young adults to struggling parents to finally getting their act together, and we get to see their whole journey. With princess (Angelina Indani) narrating, and the cute scenes featuring her and Champ (Ali Haji), their family dynamic is really wholesome and endearing. The second act of the movie does explore a lot of the struggles that Indian expats go through when they emigrate to the US, and showcases the trademark camaraderie that we’re so proud of. The friendship between RV and Harry (Javid Jaffrey), whose accent is virtually incomprehensible, but he’s hilarious, is one of the best parts of the movie. And of course, the songs and the racing. Almost all the songs and even the score are iconic to me, and the three races that they show are all really cool. RV’s struggles were devastating to watch as a kid, but the final race really made up for everything. Also Sasha was just so funny in her limited screen time that I had to give her the win, but Princess would probably have got it otherwise (her hairstyle is half of a win alone).

title: Tenet
intendedAudience: Teens and above; people who have patience for sci-fi and appreciate complex story-telling
rewatchability: You DEFINITELY need to watch this more than once to understand it completely
review: Yeah! Science! So after Avengers: Endgame I thought that I’d have had enough time-travel movies for a while. Turns out I was wrong - there’s no rejecting Nolan. So yeah, Tenet. Not gonna lie, didn’t understand everything (mostly because the version of the movie I saw wasn’t exactly the clearest), so I’m going to have to rewatch, just like everyone else who saw it the first time. That said, I did understand the plot, characters, score, etc. and they were all Nolan-esque as ever. I’d never heard of John David Washington before this role, but he’s actually a lot different from what I expected - in a good way. He comes off as likeable from the start, but still a kind of underdog. He’s got great chemistry with Neil (Robert Pattinson, who has redeemed himself as a great actor) and Kat (Elizabeth Debicki), both of whom could just as easily have been winners. Pattinson’s character always seems out of place throughout the story, and watching his arc unfold at the end of the movie is great to see. Kat and Andrei (Kenneth Branagh) have an interesting relationship too, providing most of the heavy-duty acting to the film. Supporting cast of Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Clemence Poesy, Michael Caine, Martin Donovan and Dimple Kapadia doesn’t hurt either. Of course, the score was great, loud in just the right places, though I think I wasn’t able to appreciate it to its utmost on first viewing. Otherwise, Nolan’s idea is once again entertaining as hell, pseudo-science to the core, and a must-watch for people who want a little confusion in their lives.
spoilerReview: So that machine though. That’s probably my favourite part of the whole thing. The backwards bullets and all the scenes with the reverse shots - especially the ones where some people are inverted and others aren’t - are PHENOMENAL and look like they would be SUPER hard to film, so kudos. Neil having been from the future was definitely a good twist - even if time-travel veterans might think it obvious, it was done in a way that still made it valuable. Then the end scene with Kat diving off the boat was great too. Just Nolan things, you know? And of course the I AM THE PROTAGONIST scene was hella satisfying to watch.

title: Terminator 2: Judgement Day
intendedAudience: Action movie fans, Sci-fi fans, fans of the first one
rewatchability: Once a month
review: “I’ll be back.” Man wasn’t lying. This one is better than the first one, I can say that pretty confidently. It had everything that the first had (except maybe romance, which wasn’t a big deal) and it did it all better, and MORE. Super fun, for sure. The acting was great here too: Sarah Connor (Linda Hamilton) was again the best dramatic actor here, but Edward Furlong was actually great as John, both in comedic and dramatic scenes - his chemistry with Arnold was amazing. T-800 was great this time around, and Arnold did an even better job with his visual acting. His stale delivery is the only thing that stopped me from giving him the win, even if he gave us some really iconic lines in this one too. Supporting cast of Robert Patrick and Joe Morton, as T-1000 and Miles Dyson respectively, were both great too - T-1000 is straight up the stuff of nightmares, and Patrick is great in the role. Villains are unexpectedly great in this movie. So yeah, definitely a great action movie. If you liked the first one, or Die Hard and stuff, this is for you. Also the costumes in this one are to die for - whoever thought up the iconic Sarah Connor vest is a legend.
spoilerReview: So yeah that end scene was pretty emotional, with T-800 dying. Making John a senator was a bit strange, but I get the message they were trying to offer in the end. Honestly Miles could have been MVP, since the dude was literally just a smart guy who ALSO cared about his family and was willing to sacrifice his work for the greater good. Everyone acted so well in this movie that it was that close, but the main cast definitely deserve recognition, and I chose Furlong since kid actors are hardly ever this good. The set piece at the end was the best, and I felt like the chase scene at the start wasn’t as fun as I hoped it would be. Sarah’s recurring visions were a little strange, and maybe her hospital time was a little much, but the break-out scene was SO satisfying. Also WHAT THE HELL is this movie’s deal with LICKING PEOPLE? Happened a whole TWO times, and it was just glossed over. So yeah apart from that, pretty solid.

title: The Avengers
intendedAudience: Superhero fans, action movie fans, and pretty much everyone that enjoys any combination of the two
rewatchability: Pretty long, so maybe once in a couple months
review: Has there ever been a movie with such a memorable third act? The keystone of the MCU, and its first real world-banging movie, it’s really not hard to see why everyone loves this film. Even after having watched it dozens of times, its charm was still intact, mostly thanks to great acting from the whole cast (RDJ, Chris Evans, Chris Hemsworth, ScarJo, Jeremy Renner, Sam Jackson, Tom Hiddleston), but my latest rewatch shed light on Mark Ruffalo’s Bruce Banner, who comes in at a close second winner for this movie - although he does get overshone by a lot of other characters, his character and his part in the story are played beautifully. Hiddleston’s Loki is easily one of the most memorable villains in the superhero genre, with the British class really shining through, particularly in his conversation with Black Widow. Admittedly, the first act did not shine as much as the rest of the movie, with the second act grasping the audience’s attention and the third… well, the Avengers’ third act stands as one of the best third acts in action movie history (for me, anyway). The chemistry is certainly there, and Stark’s dialogue keeps things interesting even when the plot is moving slowly. Perhaps if the first act had been shorter, and the first scene omitted, bringing the runtime down to about 2 hours as opposed to 2.5, this movie would score even higher. However, this is made up tenfold by its sheer rewatchability - owing partly to Alan Silvestri’s unspeakably iconic score.

title: The Big Short
intendedAudience: Anyone who wants to know what happened in 2008
rewatchability: Every time you want to go into a career in finance
review: I now see why everyone hates Wall Street. Kinda glad I watched this in the end - they really do make money without adding any value to society. But yeah, this movie’s cast is INSANE: Michael Burry (Christian Bale), Jared Vennet (Ryan Gosling), Ben Rickert (Brad Pitt), in addition to Carrell. Then the supporting cast with Marissa Tomei, Jamie (Finn Whitrock), Charlie (John Magaro), Margot Robbie, Selena Gomez, Karen Gillan, Anthony Bodain, Richard Thaler, and a great performance from Vinny (Jeremy Strong). But yeah, this is definitely a tragedy, and between Bale and Carrell, they communicate just how sad it is spectacularly well. Gosling adds a lot of fire, and the celebrity cameos make all the jargon easier to understand. Great filmmaking, important subject-matter. That end scene where they’re walking through the empty stock exchange is really everything.

title: The Bourne Identity
rewatchability: Once in a couple years
