review: The idea of the Bourne Identity isn’t bad in and of itself, just the execution of the movie was a bit flawed in my opinion. The action was undoubtedly the highlight of the film, with Bourne’s instinctive fighting style being extremely entertaining. The plot with Wombosi and several of the secret agents involved were quite disjointed, with there being too many subplots for the story to shine by itself. Marie (Franka Potente) had good chemistry with Damon, and his dialogue and acting carried the film. Overall, you probably wouldn’t go to the theatre to watch this, but if there was nothing else on TV, then maybe.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
rewatchability: WINNER: Prince Caspian (Ben Barnes)
review: Narnia might not be the most popular series, but I will say one thing - it has a magic that’s seldom repeated in other fantasy movies. The original Pevensie kids return in this one, Peter (William Moseley) staying as stubbornly arrogant as ever, Susan (Anna Popplewell) a little better than last time, Edmund (Skandar Keynes) a lot cooler but less important, and Lucy (Georgie Henley) who smashes it again. The supporting cast of Trumpkin (Peter Dinklage) and Nikabrik (Warwick Davis) along with Aslan (Liam Neeson) is definitely formidable, but Caspian’s charm and compelling story steals the show. It’s definitely hard to sway the audience away from their favourite heroes, but this movie manages it quite well. You can just tell that Peter and Susan don’t quite believe in Narnia’s magic as they used to, and their arcs are completed perfectly by the ending, as is Caspian’s. The music is great as usual, and the effects are amazing for their time. If anything, the movie might be a bit too long, and the sustained focus on the Telmarines takes a little away from the story.

title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader
rewatchability: Super nostalgic, once in a couple years
review: For the longest time, I can only remember hating Eustace’s character from this movie. On rewatching, it turns out that he’s actually got the best journey. And that’s really what Narnia’s all about - turning annoying kids into heroes and friends. The idea that Peter and Susan are too old to return, and Lucy (Georgie Henley) and Edmund (Skandar Keynes) are having their final adventure as kids is really heartbreaking, but keeps with the whole ‘imagination is for the young’ and ‘passing on the torch’ themes that Narnia has always been about. Ben Barnes’ Caspian is once again super charismatic, as is Liam Neeson’s Aslan. Simon Pegg’s Reepicheep (the mouse) is cute and is important to Eustace’s storyline. The music is phenomenal, the sets and costumes are awesome, and the first scene with the painting is iconic.

title: The Da Vinci Code
intendedAudience: Not kids, maybe not super conservative Christians
rewatchability: Once a year, max
review: I’d always heard a lot about this movie/book series, but I never got around to watching it until just now, and I’m happy that I finally did. As an adventure film (treasure-hunting type), it’s one of the best I’ve ever seen, taking inspiration from all kinds of history and mythology. The cast is pretty great, with Tom Hanks as Robert Langdon, Ian McKellen as Leigh Teabing, and Paul Bettany as Silas (who was great from an acting perspective). Jean Reno and Alfred Molina played good supporting roles, and Audrey Tatou is officially the best looking french person I know. Her chemistry with Hanks is great, and it’s definitely fun to watch her hold her own beside such a talented actor. In terms of the movie’s rewatchability, I’m not sure, since I’ve only seen it the one time, but that’s the thing about adventure movies - the twists are great the first time around, less so after. But I can tell that the author really did think the plot through wonderfully, giving all the characters reasonable motivations. Music was really good, the cinematography was fun to watch since they were in France and London. And despite all the possible blasphemy of the film, its moral does hold up regardless of the beliefs of the viewer.
spoilerReview: So the twists in this film are good, but I was able to predict all of them (maybe because I watch a lot of mystery, idk). Teabing as Teacher wasn’t a bad idea, and having Sophie be the holy grail in the end was a great idea, so both of those are understandable. This film really does build tension well for all the twists, which makes them even more effective. Solid watch.

title: The Devil Wears Prada
rewatchability: It’s about 2h, probably wouldn’t
review: So yeah, Anne Hathaway is Andrea, the assistant to Meryl Streep’s Miranda Preesly - a big time fashion designer - even though she wants to be a journalist. The movie is basically saying not to let your job pull you away from what’s REALLY important (friends, family, your interests, etc.) and to have the strength to know when to stop. Simultaneously it argues to be confident and open-minded to new opportunities, and that happiness will inevitably find you. All good. Emily Blunt’s character is hilarious in every way, definitely the high point of the movie.

title: The Dictator
rewatchability: Every day, it’s just comedy
review: Man, this movie. On one hand, it’s absolutely hilarious. The commentary on America and democracy through Cohen’s standard avatar frankness is definitely what makes it work. Anna Faris, Ben Kingsley, Jason Mantzoukas, and a lot of subtle cameos from other celebrities (and their lookalikes) are a solid accompaniment to Cohen’s anchoring performance. And how about that ‘Next Episode’ arabic theme? Still stuck in my head. So yeah, just super funny. Decent plot progression, too. But it’s also super offensive to anyone who treats it as anything other than a satire, so keep that in mind.

title: The Fault in Our Stars
intendedAudience: Good for all ages above maybe 15
rewatchability: Quite emotional and 2 hours+, so maybe once in a couple years
review: Ever just want to get in the feels? This is the movie you’ve been looking for. It’s got a tragic love story, two charming young characters with great chemistry, lots of cancer, parent issues, and some death. The imagery that the movie tries to represent is really what makes it special, and it highlights how idealistic teens can really be - it discusses the positives and negatives from this hopefulness in a way that’s really nice to watch. And the characters are hella cute. Obviously, Augustus Waters is an absolute legend, but his chemistry with Shailene Woodley’s Hazel Grace made most of the movie. Nat Wolff, Laura Dern, and Willem Dafoe all put in powerful supporting performances, and overall it was a great emotional journey to go on.
spoilerReview: It also deserves credit that such a sad movie can get me howling with laughter, but the scene with the egg-throwing at the car was hilarious, and cemented Augustus as a top-tier character. Also Lotte Verbeek is strangely attractive in this movie, but I’m not really complaining.

title: The Garden of Words
rewatchability: It’s 45m long, but it’s quite emotional, so maybe once every few years
review: Man, I love Shinkai - he just can’t make a bad movie. This is literally 45 minutes long, and it’s more significant than a lot of the feature-length movies I’ve seen. This one goes out to all those kids who had a crush on that one teacher in school, or on that one adult who saw you as a kid. I feel like I can’t do it justice by explaining it, but the chemistry between Yukino and Takao (Miyu Irino) is so authentic and relatable that you start to root for them even though there’s 12 years of an age difference and he’s a minor (the movie is fully legal though, don’t worry). But yeah, the music, the animation, the characters, the motifs… Shinkai just knocks it all out of the park. And although there might be some weirder elements in this particular film, it’s definitely got the heart to back it up.
spoilerReview: Man, that last scene. I feel like I say that a lot, but Shinkai, so bear with me. Massive props to the voice actor for Yukino when she cried out and gave Takao the hug at the end - I got goosebumps at the voice. Great acting. The reveal that she was a teacher did surprise me, but I guess it did make sense. The whole ‘tanka’ poem callback from her being a English Literature teacher was really beautiful too, fitting in with the whole ‘garden’ aspect of the movie. And it’s just so funny to watch a teacher and a kid talk about drinking in the morning while they skip school. But yeah, that last scene when Takao is yelling at her and she’s crying… fabulous. And the post credits of him leaving the shoes for her in the park was a great ending too. Solid. Would definitely watch a longer version.

title: The Godfather
intendedAudience: Not kids, and teens probably wouldn’t appreciate it
rewatchability: Once a year, maybe
review: From a critical point of view, it doesn’t surprise me that this movie is considered one of the greatest of all time. The storytelling was notable, even if the initial wedding scene was tediously lengthy. Between Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, the Corleone Family stands as one of the most iconic gangster families ever, and I had the hardest time deciding the winner, which came to Brando’s delivery and presence (even if Michael Corleone was my personal favorite). The supporting characters (Sonny, Tom, Sollozzo, etc.) were pretty solid too. The world-building was brilliant, and the parallels of the first and last scene make it clear to the audience that the directors knew what they were doing.

title: The Godfather: Part II
intendedAudience: Not kids, and teens probably wouldn’t appreciate it
review: The second godfather isn’t as good as the first, but is refreshing in that its strengths stem both from those of its predecessor and have an element of uniqueness. The inclusion of Robert Deniro as a young Vito Corleone as masterful, and his portrayal made my choosing a winner for this movie almost as hard as the previous film. The story was far less contained than in the previous film, which is saying a lot, especially because this one is 3.5 hours long, and doesn’t have Marlon Brando. That said, Michael’s character arc is continued to perfection, showing us the detriments of his time as Don, and the effect on the Corleone Family.

title: The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly
rewatchability: 3h, but a classic
review: WOOH! That score is just wonderful. If you’ve never heard it (which should be impossible), go do that now. Iconic if there ever was a real definition for the word. The main cast was all phenomenal in their roles: The Man With No Name (Clint Eastwood) was the Good, Angel Eyes (Lee Van Cleef) was the Bad, and Tuco was the Ugly, but there wasn’t too much separating them. Each one of them could hold a screen by themselves. Also, can I just say, if this was a show instead of a 3h movie, it would DEMOLISH all the streaming services. This is basically the Mandalorian oozing with charisma (granted, with less Star Wars references). The Civil War backdrop was interesting, but also a little distracting, but the main arc of the characters was quite entertaining. The Music. Definitely a classic.
spoilerReview: So many iconic scenes for this one. The showdown at the end was awesome - Blondie kept faking people out, it was pretty funny. The absolute end when he came back to free Tuco after almost forcing him to hang himself (payback for the desert torture) was definitely cool. The grave finding scene with the score in the back was absolutely enjoyable. And damn, the shooting display was awesome. Great chemistry all around, too. Tuco’s acting was really great, and it’s so impressive how the movie holds up even 60 years after its release.

title: The Greatest Showman
intendedAudience: Kids can watch, it’s pretty wholesome
rewatchability: Once a year, maybe
review: Everyone loves an underdog. Everyone loves a big heart. But an underdog with a big heart? With the face of Hugh Jackman? Love isn’t enough. This movie’s soundtrack is one of the best I’ve heard, and it has a crazy good plot for a musical. There’s a lot of heart, there’s chemistry, there’s character development. I don’t remember there being much wrong with this movie, to be honest. The only thing was that it didn’t really have any iconic or mindblowing kind of moments that helped it stand out.

title: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey
intendedAudience: People who like fantasy, lord of the rings
rewatchability: It’s mostly jovial, but 3h
review: I feel like this captures the right feeling, hitting all the nostalgic spots for Lord of the Rings fans and exploring all aspects of the great world and characters it introduces. But it’s also 1/3rd of a series, and it’s 3 hours long - they waste so much time. Highlights include Elrond (Hugo Weaving), Gandalf (Ian McKellen), Thorin (Richard Armitage), and Gollum (Andy Serkis). Music and sets were obviously wonderful, costumes were cool, and even the emotional storytelling wasn’t bad, but it just took way too long with so few events. Also the many callbacks might make it seem like a rehash of the original series. Big fan of Freeman’s Bilbo though, who’s really funny and charming.

title: The Hunchback of Notre Dame
intendedAudience: Could be anyone; this is more an ideological movie than anything else
review: So I think french people are quite good at writing stories. This one in particular is really cool because its main character actually doesn’t have most of the protagonist-type tropes. That said, Quasimodo (Tom Hulce) is a really likeable hero, and Frollo (Tony Jay) is a completely despicable villain. Esmeralda steals the show in terms of agency and personality, and Phoebus’ (Kevin Kline) one-liners are SO GOOD that I almost considered him winning just because of that. Music was phenomenal, and the plot was great too. The story isn’t so far-fetched that you might even believe it happening in real life, which makes it that much scarier. Definitely one of the more real disney films, even though the supporting cast of talking gargoyles were pretty hilarious.
spoilerReview: So Esmeralda has a little too good chemistry with everyone, because everyone’s in love with her - Quasimodo not ending up with her was an interesting choice, but also a little sad to think about. Frollo’s solo song was actually great for character, and the final scene was great character work. Phoebus was cool, but I feel like maybe he didn’t really need to exist? The scene with Quasimodo in the festival was great too. All-around very well done.

title: The Imitation Game
intendedAudience: Pretty much anyone, maybe barring little kids
rewatchability: Probably every nine months or so
review: The role of Alan Turing draws on the same part of Cumberbatch’s acting as Sherlock Holmes or Doctor Strange (arrogant, unlikeable genius) while still making you want to root for him, for some reason. Whenever Turing was being a jerk to his colleagues, I was a little torn between being on their side and wanting to see his unique way of tackling a problem play out. Keira Knightley is also great, though it would’ve been nice if her character had had more to do. Then again, this movie is set during World War II, so I can see how the filmmakers struggled with that. The score is great, and was actually nominated for an Oscar before losing out to another score by the same composer, which kind of says all that needs to be said. The movie overall is ALL ABOUT THE SECRETS (makes sense), and as such can get pretty depressing despite a reasonable amount of levity. Turing’s sexuality is handled pretty well, if not completely accurately. To be honest, most of this movie took a few liberties with regard to history, but it all works to make the film better, so I’ll allow it. I’m pretty sure there’s a Game of Thrones actor in there somewhere too.

title: The Incredibles
rewatchability: It’s around 2h, but I remember I used to watch it almost once a month
review: Ah, the Incredibles. It was so good that they made a sequel 14 years after. There really is nothing more to say, is there? The characters were all SO nuanced and believable, with SO MUCH iconic dialogue and SO MANY iconic scenes. Who thought a family superhero movie would be what we wanted? Still great, even if the animation has gotten out of style. Honestly, Holly Hunter’s little speech pattern thing itself made Helen so much more real as a person, Violet was the perfect reclusive highschooler, Dash was a real annoying younger sibling, and Bob’s character flaws made the movie. Of course, the supporting cast of Lucius/Frozone (Samuel L Jackson, who’s amazing as usual), Syndrome (Jason Lee, who’s actually a well-crafted villain), and Edna (absolute scene-stealer) are just gems of performances too. So yeah, there’s always some kind of tension in the plot to keep things moving, and there’s lots of comedy too. Overall absolutely solid watch for superhero fans.

title: The Irishman
rewatchability: Never
review: So this is probably the longest movie in history. Three and a half hours long, and there’s pretty much no reason for it to be - the whole last half hour is pointless as hell. Plot-wise, there isn’t really that much going on either - it really looks like it’s trying to be like the Godfather. They definitely have a talented enough cast (Robert de Niro, Al Pacino, Joe Petsci, Bobby Cannavale, Anna Paquin), but it’s really really tedious to sit through - nearly impossible for one sitting. The music was notably pretty good - because Scorsese is Scorsese - and the acting was as one would expect from these distinguished thespians. The ending was pretty upsetting, but in a ‘wth-was-that-for’ kinda way.

title: The Lion King
intendedAudience: Meant for kids, and teaches them a lot
rewatchability: As a kid, you can rewatch pretty much every day, except for some trauma
review: The crown jewel of Disney and animated cinema as a whole, the Lion King is and will likely stay as the essential childhood movie. The opening itself is one of the most iconic in cinema history, with the cultural representation of Africa really shining through at first, followed up by the masterful “Circle of Life”. For an animated movie, the performances were also unbelievable, making it almost impossible for me to pick a winner. Between Jeremy Irons’ Scar - one of the most Shakespearian villains of all time - Rowan Atkinson’s Zazu, John Kani’s Rafiki, Matthew Broderick’s Adult Simba, and Nathan Lane and Ernie Sabella’s Timon and Pumbaa, there were almost no non-iconic characters in the film. Given that it was based off of Hamlet, it isn’t all that surprising that the film’s plot is well crafted and meaningful, but it is also masterfully complemented with some of the most tasteful songs in cinema history, perfectly capturing the characters’ moods and themes as the film progressed (“I Just Can’t Wait to Be King”, “Hakuna Matata”, “Can You Feel The Love Tonight”). With lots of creative input and imagery slotted in for older viewers, this movie leaves absolutely nothing to want, with every scene seemingly flawless - it will definitely always be one of the greats for me, even if my childhood nostalgic bias is in effect.
spoilerReview: Honestly, as mind-blowing as the film is, it has remained one of the most iconic pieces of cinema in history because of one bold scene - Mufasa’s death. Such an unexpected moment in a children’s movie was really a stroke of genius, allowing parents to introduce their children to the idea of death together as Simba’s understanding grows, and the “Circle of Life” theme giving them a constructive yet realistic understanding of a normally ghastly idea.

title: The Little Mermaid
review: UNDA DA SEA. This movie isn’t perfect, but watching it fully in 2021 for the first time, I’m so happy to see what high quality movies we had around us as kids. Ariel is pretty impulsive and easy to fall in love, but apart from that she’s a likeable protagonist, and the way she’s animated is really iconic. Jodi Benson’s voice is just so amazing as well, and Part of Your World is such a dreamy song that most kids can relate to. King Triton (Kenneth Mars) is actually a good parent throughout, and Sebastian plays the Mushu role of escorting the protagonist through the plot with lots of comic relief. Prince Eric (Christopher Daniel Barnes) is super handsome, and his character isn’t bad, having been fixated on finding the owner of Ariel’s beautiful voice. I’m a huge fan of his butler Grimsby (Ben Wright) also. The plot pacing, animation, songs, score, side characters, and dialogue were all held to a REALLY high standard, and I think it’s probably right that this is considered the start of Disney’s golden age of animated movies.
spoilerReview: Wow, so Ariel giving away her voice was interesting, even if it’s a REALLY BAD DEAL to take along with the servitude thing. Her fish out of water scenes were cool, and Kiss the Girl with Eric was a really beautiful scene. Yay Sebastian. Now Ursula (Pat Carroll) obviously didn’t have the clearest motivations, but she was definitely really scary and her voice + design were both on point. Her turning into a massive monster and getting impaled by a ship was pretty stupid though. Also having Eric kill her seems undeserved, but I guess Ariel was a little indisposed. The mind-control voice stuff was pretty unnecessary I think, and it would have just been better to have Eric WANT to marry the person with that voice. Also Triton swapping in for Ariel was a really nice scene, just like the ending where she gets legs again.

title: The Little Prince
rewatchability: Only a little longer than 1
review: This may be the best thing ever created by French people. A stellar cast of Mackenzie Foy, Rachel McAdams, Jeff Bridges, Marion Cotillard, James Franco, Ricky Gervias, Paul Rudd, and Benecio del Toro should be enough to get you to watch any film - and the animation doesn’t take away from the emotion. The portrayal of contemporary education is hurtfully realistic, and the theme that children should be encouraged to facilitate their imaginations is both beautiful in planning and execution. The friendship between the little girl and the aviator can inspire emotion in even the most stone-faced audiences, and as remarkable as their plotline is, the Little Prince himself takes the crown for me. His story and character perfectly portray the innocence and purity of childhood, and his idealism will make everyone wish that they’d taken just a little longer to grow up. Throw in some well-placed music and decent visuals, and the heart of the movie gets fair treatment - definitely worth a watch.
spoilerReview: The ‘school’ plot was a decent opener to the film, but wasn’t exactly consistently followed-up until the very end. Not really anything to complain about, since it left more time for the little girl to find the little prince, and ending both of their character arcs together was particularly impactful. The sunrise motif was visually and thematically a wonderful inclusion too, and the fox proved to be a pretty funny comedic aid.

title: The Matrix Reloaded
rewatchability: 2h, but feels a bit long at times
review: Better than I thought it would be, honestly. People don’t give this one enough credit - it keeps up the spirit of the first and builds on the world and the lore in wonderful fashion. If anything, maybe they spent a little too much time on those little matrix-y things that made the plot a little less linear than we would have liked. The action scenes were iconic in genuine matrix style, but they were a little too long for my taste as well, and shorter fights would have made for better pacing and lesser runtime, both of which would be the main areas of improvement here. Still, the plot was catchy and interesting, and definitely keeps you on your toes. Acting-wise, I can’t decide if everyone was good or okay, but Neo (Keanu Reeves), Morpheus (Lawrence Fishburne) and Trinity all did great with the dialogue they were given. Costumes were also awesome as usual. Supporting acts from Smith (Hugo Weaving), Persephone (Monica Bellucci), and Merovingian (Lambert Wilson) were all fun and entertaining, while Niobe (Jada Pinkett Smith) provided some star power. The “program” supporting actors also did a pretty great job playing non-humans, in my opinion.
spoilerReview: I really liked how they made some programs not evil - it explained the origin of the Oracle from the first movie and the Keymaker and Architect from this one. Definitely cool. Neo’s new powers are pretty dope. I guess the ending cliffhanger is pretty annoying, especially since now I have to watch another 2h movie, but it’s definitely a good marketing technique. Guess I’m watching Revolutions now.

title: The Matrix Revolutions
rewatchability: 2h, but feels a bit long at times
review: As far as sci-fi thrillers go, this one is pretty definitive. It has the exact same flaws as its immediate predecessor (overall length, battles were too long, pacing) but has the X-factor of actually having an ending, which is always nice. A lot of character arcs are also fulfilled in this one, particularly for minor characters, which we love to see. Keanu Reeves is just as good as Neo, but once again I prefer Moss’ acting style (they both lean toward less visual acting, but her performance seemed more lively) as a lead. Morpheus (Lawrence Fishburne) was unfortunately sidelined, while Niobe (Jada Pinkett-Smith) was awesome in this one. Monica Bellucci’s Persephone was wasted, but Hugo Weaving probably played his best Smith in this iteration. So yeah, it’s definitely a solid ending to the series, even if the finer details are hazy if you think about them too much.
spoilerReview: There’s SO much Jesus imagery going on with Neo at the end. The final fight ends in a pretty weird way, since everyone just explodes - I didn’t understand why Neo gave up and then Smith died. But the Oracle definitely pulled through in this one; great arc for her. I did really like both the surface scenes with Neo and Trinity as well as Niobe’s driving, but the main fight in Zion was mostly chaos. Still, the bit with Mifune and the kid was great. There really are a lot of notable actors in this movie; I recognized two from the Power Rangers series alone, so make of that what you will. But yeah, the final compromise between Neo and the machines seems a little tentative, but it works as an end to his arc.

title: The Nanny Diaries
rewatchability: Probably wouldn’t
review: So I pretty much only watched this for the Scarlett Johansson and Hayden (Chris Evans) chemistry before the MCU. Turns out that that’s the only watchable part of this movie. The end scene with her yelling at the parents was pretty great too, and I think Scarlett gets the short end of the stick for her acting. Chris Evans was pretty great as usual, but the little kid was annoying, and the parents were just the worst, and Annie’s friends weren’t too exciting either. Pretty tedious plot.

title: The Prince of Egypt
intendedAudience: Works well with anyone who’s willing to keep an open mind and enjoy a story
rewatchability: Three times a year, maybe
review: Obviously, I’m not Jewish, and I’m not too into “faith” as it is, but there’s no denying that the story of Moses (at least as told in this movie) is beautiful. The relationship between Moses and Ramses (Ralph Fiennes) was extremely powerful and was the emotional basis for the entire movie, and even though Set I (Patrick Stewart) was objectively ruthless, both his and Ramses’ actions were understandable in their own twisted ways. The incorporation of Zipporah (Michelle Pfeiffer) to the plot as Moses’ catalyst was great, as was the occasional shift to Miriam’s (Sandra Bullock) point of view. Overall, the music was another highlight of the movie—hebrew chanting is really nice to hear, and the “deliver us” theme was actually great. Aaron’s (Jeff Goldblum) arc wasn’t bad, and was the most believable in my opinion, even if he was meant to be some kind of a bystander. So overall, if you can treat a little religious propagation as a learning experience, you’ll find that this is actually a great movie to watch for all ages.
spoilerReview: Watching Moses go from the child of slaves to an ignorant prince to the prophet that he’s known to be was definitely an impressive character arc to say the least. Ramses going from eager prince to a king with a chip on his shoulder was a brilliant arc as well, and the last scene with his son’s death and him calling for Moses at the end was heart-breaking. The animation was great throughout, but particularly in the miracles scenes, as well as whenever “God” showed up. I don’t know if I’m allowed to have issues with the plot, but I did feel that there was a lot of bona fide deus ex machina involved whenever he faced conflict. But given that faith is the main theme of this movie, I guess that’s to be expected.

title: The Princess Bride
intendedAudience: Fun for kids, entertaining for adults
rewatchability: As often as you want, it’s only 1h30
review: Holy quotable lines. I knew that the characters from this movie were iconic before I even watched it, and it was easy to see why. Between Inigo Montoya’s catchphrase and The Dread Pirate’s charm (which almost gave him the win), there’s plenty of comedy in this INCONCEIVABLE movie. The theme and characters are great for kids, and adults would appreciate the fantasy aspect of this fairy-tale-esque story. The chemistry between Inigo and Fezzik was fun, even if Fezzik annoyed me a bit. The Prince and the Count were decent villains, and Buttercup was a strong female character. The whole premise with the plot being a storybook made it a little frustrating every time the kid interrupted, but the grandpa-kid relationship was cute.
spoilerReview: Vizzini annoyed me beyond belief, so it was fun to watch him die. Westley and Inigo’s fight and their interactions later were hilarious too. Miracle Max and Valerie were hilarious too, and Inigo’s final fight was a great ending.

title: The Princess Diaries 2: Royal Engagement
intendedAudience: School kids, people who enjoy romcoms
rewatchability: It’s 1h55, maybe a rare one-off rewatch
review: I’ll watch two hours of funny Anne Hathaway most days. They pretty much make use of most of the charm of the original, and bringing in Nicholas (Chris Pine) did wonders for chemistry, even though his uncle (John Rhys-Davies) was really not the best antagonist. The message and ending wasn’t bad, but the overall plot did seem to revolve a lot around Mia enjoying herself in Genovia as Princess, and rehashing a lot of the same comedy from the first movie. Not bad for fans of the original, but wouldn’t necessarily watch more than once.

title: The Shawshank Redemption
rewatchability: It’s 2h20, and it’s kind of a once-in-a-lifetime experience
review: This is widely touted as the best movie ever made, and I can definitely see the angle that people are coming from. Red’s (Morgan Freeman) narration was always going to be spectacular, but his chemistry with Andy was unreal. They both had such emotional performances that it was easy to want to keep watching. Prison life is awful, that’s no secret, but the story makes use of that tragedy to build such profound hope that it can give you faith in life no matter what you think has happened. Stephen King’s story was incredibly nuanced in the way only a novel can be, and the inclusion of all sorts of worldly practices into the greater metaphor for their struggle makes the movie that much grander - it feels like “no matter how bad you think it is, you’ll be fine.” And there’s definitely a lot of pain in the movie, so it isn’t exactly pleasant always, but you’ll definitely feel reassured after watching. That’s all I have for you.
spoilerReview: Whoo! That rain scene! The catharsis was spectacular. I will say, this movie did well in that I didn’t know how it was going to end until it did. And damn, I hated that warden. SO glad that literally every antagonist got screwed over, but also RIP to the fallen heroes. There’s just a real sense of gravity about this movie, and I feel like I need to compare it to Good Will Hunting to explain. So yeah, I feel like I’ll rewatch this every 10 years until I die, and every time it’ll feel different. So until next time, get busy living, or get busy dying.

title: The Shining
rewatchability: It’s 2h, but also the plot is just weird, so probably wouldn’t
review: Bruh, Kubrick. I swear I can never understand your movies. They straight up don’t make any sense. There were really only 4 characters - Wendy (Shelley Duvall), Danny (Danny Lloyd), and Mr. Hallorann (Scatman Crothers), in addition to Jack, and they were all so polar. Jack was okay in the start, but man got SO weird as it went on - I honestly just got scared looking at Nicholson’s face most of the time. Wendy was a total sweetheart throughout (honestly feel bad for her), the kid was pretty annoying, and Hallorann did nothing. I will say that the score was great, since horror movies do depend on that a lot, and the direction was interesting. Obviously, there’s that iconic scene with the axe, which is great, but most of it is just slowly building up tension until insanity. Lots of suspense, relatively engaging, but it’s quite slow and isn’t really spectacular or emotional. Makes it a bit hard to watch.
spoilerReview: I know it’s based on a book, which I’m sure is great (Stephen King and all), but the plot is pretty basic too. The ending was pretty satisfying, even if I didn’t understand the meaning of the ball dance picture. “The shining” trait that Danny and Hallorann share is pretty cool in theory, but it’s effectively just a sharp noise and a weird expression, which is annoying as hell to watch. The fact that the movie has the n word has aged extremely poorly (even if there was a reason for it, as I understand) and didn’t help its judgement. So yeah, Jack Nicholson is scary, Kubrick is scary, King is scary. Movie is mostly ‘eh’ with iconic bits here and there and a lot of suspense. Let it be known that I’m not a horror fan.

title: The Social Dilemma
rewatchability: Wouldn’t, but keep remembering what they’re saying
review: Straight up scared the life out of me. I was actually so angry in the middle that I had to take a break when the little girl was looking at herself in the mirror. The plot with Ben was okay to prove their point, but the experts really talk really well. Tristan, Tim Kendall, Jaron Lanier, etc. had all seen their algorithms at work and it was obvious that they were talking with great urgency and genuine heart. So yeah I’m definitely going to try to a) remember what they said, and b) find some resistance to getting swept up in all this people-packaging.

title: The Sound of Music
rewatchability: It’s a solid 3 hours long, so maybe once a year
review: If we were ranking movie soundtracks, this movie would - by all measure of my thought right now - be masterclass captain. Every single song in this movie is more than just iconic, and has shaped pop-culture and the childhood of gen Y and Z in ways that transcend conventional cinema. The plot and acting in the film is pretty phenomenal too, with the Von Trapp Family and Maria (Julie Andrews) serving as solid leads with the Baroness (Eleanor Parker) and Max (Richard Hadyn) acting as decent supporting cast, with the standard all-time antagonists in the form of the nazis. The movie is always wonderful to look at, with the setting choice lending a lot to this, and Liesl (Charmian Carr) too. Lots of good family values, and overall things to admire.

title: The Suicide Squad
rewatchability: Airplanes, maybe
review: Pretty funny, overall. I think the main cast of the movie were all great: Bloodsport (Idris Elba), Peacemaker (John Cena), Harley Quinn (Margot Robbie), and Ratcatcher II were all really funny, and were utilized to really good effect. Nanaue/King Shark was absolutely hilarious and really precious, and I would honestly give him the win, but Ratcatcher was just as awesome, and Daniela Melchior is really good-looking. Harley’s plot was pretty funny, and I thought the opening scene idea was really great from James Gunn, whose bright colours and interesting text cards make this movie a lot more watchable than the previous suicide squad movie. Weasel (Sylvester Stallone) and Blackguard (Pete Davidson) were also funny. Polkadot Man (David Dastmalchian) and Rick Flag (Joel Kinnaman) were also funny, and I think Gunn figured out how to improve on characters like Flag and Amanda Waller (Viola Davis) to better suit the plot. Pretty funny throughout, would have liked a shorter, more compact story, and the final scene was just insane (in a crazy way). The political subtext was on point.

title: The Terminator
intendedAudience: Pretty much everyone already knows it, but people who like action movies will enjoy
rewatchability: Once a week if you want, 1h45
review: “Come with me if you want to live.” Even if you haven’t seen the movie, you must have heard that somewhere, and that’s honestly the biggest problem with this movie - everyone is too familiar with it. I hadn’t watched the whole thing before, but I already knew all the characters and the basic plot, as well as most of the iconic lines (there are a LOT of these, and they’re still great). I guess that’s saying it was too successful, which is crazy. T-800 (Arnold Schwarzenegger) was obviously the centerpiece of the movie, and even though his delivery was (iconically) robotic, his visual presence was terrifying enough to make him a great antagonist. Reese (Michael Biehn) and Sarah were pretty great protagonists overall, not wasting time or squandering suspense, but also retaining relevant character moments. I guess suspense is the main high point with this movie, in both the plot and the music. It was mostly fast paced, even if the beginning was a little drawn out. The Sci-fi elements are cool (even if I wish they were modernized) and very 80s, so it might seem a little old-fashioned now, but they’re still entertaining stories. I look forward to the sequel.
spoilerReview: The last scene was a great circle to the story, and was arguably one of the stronger scenes overall, with the whole picture and everything. I figured that Reese would be the dad from about halfway through the movie, but the scenes in the future were cool to see, and John Connor’s reputation is even more meaningful since I know we’ll see him in future movies. I was expecting Sarah Connor to be a badass in this one, I’ll admit, so I was wondering why she wasn’t just killing T-800, but her character growth was pretty great overall. Best believe I would definitely have died if I was in her place - and she didn’t even have plot armour, since the movie was pretty grounded. So yeah, Reese was cool too. Overall fun to watch.

title: The Theory of Everything
rewatchability: It’s 2h and extremely heavy, but really beautiful
review: It’s funny how one of the best love stories of all time is not only real, but is largely unrecognized. And this is a love story - if there’s any doubt, google this movie and see who it’s written by (it’s Jane Hawking). Watching this after Stephen passed away (in real life) made the story bite that much more, and I have the utmost respect for both him and Jane. Eddie Redmayne (is unfairly charming here) and Felicity Jones (an absolute dream) do a great job of portraying them respectively, and both of their acting skills would make any movie worth watching. The music and shooting style really accentuate all the strongest emotional moments and really allow the story to shine. There’s tragedy, comedy, heart, and realism sorted in portions that only reality itself can perfect. And of course, the physics speaks for itself.

title: The Way of the Dragon
intendedAudience: People who like martial arts movies
rewatchability: It’s mostly action, so at your own pleasure
review: RIP Bruce Lee. I’ve only just realized how awesome this man was, and I’m glad that there’s so much material that the world can remember him by. This movie isn’t one I’d normally watch, given that it’s in Chinese and feels like it has a lot of latent nationalistic undertones, but as an action movie, there’s no denying that it’s as enjoyable as anything else. Lee’s martial arts are amazing as always, and his interaction with Chin Hua (Nora Miao) - who’s really pretty and does a great job herself - builds most of the movie. You get to see a lot of Rome, which is nice, but the thing that sets this movie aside from most other martial arts movies is the final fight. Bruce Lee vs Chuck Norris (who plays Colt, who’s basically just Chuck Norris) at the Colosseum. If that’s doesn’t make your eyes widen, then this isn’t for you. But as one of the best martial arts fights on screen, it’s definitely a win for authentic action.
spoilerReview: Can’t believe Bruce Lee straight up kills Chuck Norris. What a savage. Also the darts are a cool way to battle guns. But I didn’t understand what was up with Lee’s character having to use the washroom every five minutes, that was pretty strange.

title: The Worst Person in the World
intendedAudience: Anyone above eighteen can probably find something to relate to here
rewatchability: The movie is built enough around subtext that deciphering it takes some brainpower, so eight or nine months at least
review: At first glance, It’s a little weird how this movie’s plot never really seems to go anywhere, but I guess the more I think about it the more convinced I become that the lack of a definite conflict worked well with the message it was trying to send. The Worst Person in the World feels less like a story and more like an episodic character study on its protagonist (Renate Reinsve), a young woman fresh out of college trying to find her place in the world. The title is kind of left open to interpretation as well—it’s a bit of a running joke for my friends and me to randomly ask one another, “So, who is the worst person in the world?” Very artsy, very clearly an indie film, and definitely made me want to move to Oslo (did I mention it’s in Norwegian? Well, now you know). If anything, the ending felt a little rushed, and the movie took a lot of time fleshing out its main questions at the expense of actually answering them. Of course, there’s no one way of figuring out your life, but I was hoping to at least come out of the theater with a sense of how Julie came to that realization herself. There’s some pretty funny social commentary as well, so that’s something to look forward to.

title: Titanic
intendedAudience: Not kids, but pretty much everyone else should appreciate it
rewatchability: It’s decently rewatchable, but it’s 3 hours long, so you need some time
review: This movie deserves all the money it earned; it’s not hard to realize why it made as much as it did - young Leo with a special charm and the grandness of the biggest ship in the world, coupled with an iconic score and beautiful cinematography… they didn’t miss any tricks. Titanic is a sound narrative, with Jack and Rose’s story being my personal Romeo and Juliet equivalent. The dialogue between them is charming, and Jack’s underdog story makes him impossible not to root for. Cal is hilariously easy to dislike, and despite the fact that Kate Winslet’s Rose wasn’t as iconic as Jack, her character arc was charmingly completed and complemented by Jack’s. I’m not a Celine Dion fan, but “My Heart Will Go On” is a classic, and fits this movie to the T. James Cameron has got the blockbuster blueprint pretty well-set, and if this movie could have been about 2 hours instead of 3, it would have definitely made it to at least CC.
spoilerReview: ROSE KILLED JACK. Okay, that aside, it really shouldn’t have taken a full hour for the Titanic to sink. It might have helped the sense of urgency if it had been… urgent. Anyway, Rose throwing the heart of the ocean into the ocean at the end was cool, and the end scene with them back in the titanic was a nice ending.

title: To All the Boys: Always and Forever
rewatchability: It’s pretty much only applicable to teens, so as many times as you want in your teens
review: Best one out of the three, if my memory holds true. Easily the one with the best message. Somehow these movies use very real, relatable romantic things that kids do and mesh it well with a totally stylized version of high school in a functional way - that’s what makes everything so attractive to audiences. Lara Jean (Lara Condor) and Peter Kavinsky (Noah Centineo) are perfect representations of the target audience’s high school ideal, and their relationship is well written in terms of dialogue. The plot was super promising upto the second act (which is rare for these kinds of movies) and the New York scenes were all actually the best. Of course, the fact that all the transitions have kpop is a massive plus for me. But the story was straightforward and incredibly believable, and even though I had hoped they had the guts to handle it a little bravely, I think I’m satisfied with the ending. Peter’s dad’s scene at the end was well done, and justified the ending. Graduation scene did make me a little melancholy, not going to lie. Also, supporting cast is awesome, with Trevor (Ross Butler), Margot (Janel Parrish), and Chris (Madeleine Arthur), with Kitty taking home the win for being just the purest little sibling ever. I guess there’s still a little high school left in me.

title: Top Gun
rewatchability: Can hit hard, but is also awesome, so once a couple months
review: This is one of the most hype movies ever, not gonna lie. The soundtrack, mixed in with the pure triumph of flying the way Maverick does, is the biggest adrenaline boost in any movie that I can remember. There’s a great overall acting job from the cast: Iceman (Val Kilmer), Goose (Anthony Edwards), Viper (Tom Skerritt), and Charlie (Kelly McGillis) were all perfect in their roles, and had great chemistry with Cruise. The outfits were awesome, and the 80s nuance was really cool to see. Dialogue was hella iconic and quotable, which made the interactions that much better. All the flying around could make you a little dizzy though.
spoilerReview: Gahh the Goose death was obviously really sad, and he was pretty awesome. The whole thing with Maverick’s dad was pretty weird, but it was good for explaining his character, I guess. I would have liked to see a little more of Iceman’s actual flying before he won the prize, but I guess that would have taken away from the story. Charlie coming back at the end was cute, and all the random singing scenes slapped lmao.

title: Vampires Suck
intendedAudience: People who know about Twilight and have watched the movies
rewatchability: After you watch twilight
review: This is like an abridged version of Twilight that breaks the fourth wall and pokes fun at all the problems with the story, the acting, and the dialogue in the original movie. Honestly, I thought Becca was better than Bella, and Jenn Priske is really pretty and does an amazing job imitating Kristen Stewart. Edward (Matt Lanter) looked surprisingly similar to Robert Pattinson, and even though I just know him as the voice of Anakin Skywalker in the CW animated series, he was really funny as Edward. Whoever wrote the dialogue is probably a fan of the real series/movies, and the final battle with Daro (Ken Jeong) is hilarious. The whole Team Edward vs Team Jacob bit is funny too, and Jacob (Chris Riggi) is utilized even better in this version. Very good vampire puns.

title: Venom
rewatchability: 2h00, pretty fast paced
review: Yoooo, I really didn’t expect this to be as good as it was - I have to say, the advertising for this movie really didn’t do it justice. No seriously, this is basically the Sony equivalent of Iron Man - the only thing that sets them apart is RDJ and color. That said, Carlton Drake (Riz Ahmed) was a fantastic villain, and his encounters with Eddie (Tom Hardy) were great. The highlight of the movie for me was when Venom and Eddie started talking to each other - instant gold. Annie (Michelle Williams) was a passable female lead, along with Jenny Slate, whose quirky vibe was good for keeping the start of the movie fresh, and the plot was pretty solid overall. The whole symbiote science system worked really well with the villain’s ideals, and the Venom vs Riot fight at the end was great. Basically, any scene that actually included Venom was fabulous. Definitely worth a watch; I know I’m going to watch the sequel.
spoilerReview: HAHA that kiss scene was actually hilarious. Full props to whoever thought that up. The Carnage setup was cool, and the Spider-Verse snippet was appreciated (even though I saw that before this), even if it didn’t do that movie justice. So I guess Sony just doesn’t know how to market stuff, because obviously ITSV was awesome, and this was great too.

title: WALL-E
rewatchability: It’s 1h45, starts slow but picks up and doesn’t stop
review: I don’t know how Pixar do it. Their movies are all so unique in setting and conception, but all still manage to address really important themes - and this might just be their most impressive work. It’s unbelievably hard to make a compelling and entertaining movie when both your main characters actually can’t speak a coherent language (they have pokemon vocabulary), but WALL-E (Ben Burtt) and EVE were two of the most heart-wrenching characters I’ve ever watched, and they barely have faces. Plot, music, situation, all masterfully crafted; characters were iconic and well thought-out - Captain McCrea (Jeff Garlin) was particularly good, but the robots ruled this one. The animation and attention to detail regarding their facial expressions was what made the movie, alongside the sound mixing and effects (them saying each others’ names is just adorable). There’s drama, romance, heart, redemption, and a critique on humanity’s gluttony and environmental indifference; all in all, I’d be happy if kids learned anything at all from this movie.

title: WarGames
rewatchability: Once a couple years
review: Yeah, Matthew Broderick is definitely my fav actor. I had to skip past the starting ten-ish minutes of the movie, but as soon as he showed up, it was a lot more fun. All the adults in the movie were pretty boring, except for Stephen Falken (John Wood), who’s pretty weird. Also Ally Sheedy’s Jennifer is cute AS HELL, I think I might be in love. And her chemistry with David was awesome, and her 80s vibe is super attractive for some reason. Obviously there’s a big message here about nuclear war, but “Shall we play a game” still SENDS.

title: Weathering With You
rewatchability: Around 2h, but quite eventful, maybe once a year
review: I don’t even speak japanese, but the main theme for this movie is stuck in my head. It’s really an interesting story, what with Hina being a ‘sunshine-girl’ and Hodaka’s (Kotaro Daigo) relationship with her. Of course, Shinkai’s animation, music, and inspiration are all unmatched, and the supporting cast were great this time around as well. Keisuke (Shun Oguri) was a welcome change in tone, while Natsumi (Tsubasa Honda) and Nagi (Sakura Kiryu) were great for comedic and heartfelt scenes. Everything to do with the torii gates and the skyworld was breathtaking, and the last act was beautiful as well.
spoilerReview: Man, I absolutely FREAKED OUT when I saw Taki and Mitsuha (from Your Name) show up in cameos. Made my day. Taki’s grandmother was a pretty fun character here too, which I appreciate a lot. I guess the movie was great overall, but the consequences for being a fugitive looked like they were super lax, and the movie did seem a little longer than it could have been. Still, the end scene definitely capitalized on most of the movie, and it was all beautiful as always.

title: Weekend at Bernie’s
rewatchability: 1h30 and funny, even if the start is a little slow
review: These years just brought out the most hilarious movies. This movie is just a genuine comedy buddy movie, with Larry and Richard (Jonathan Silverman) just messing around for an hour and a half, and it’s HILARIOUS. Sure, it starts a little slow, but once they get to the island it’s absolutely hilarious. The plot is surprisingly comprehensive for a comedy, and the physical comedy of Bernie (Terry Kiser) and Paulie (Don Calfa) is a really good complement to Larry’s confident and Richard’s docile comedy. Gwen (Catherine Mary Stewart) and Tina (Catherine Parks) were both pretty funny, but the only real characters in the movie were Larry and Richard, and the movie works great centered around those two. I feel like it would be hilarious to watch with friends.

title: West Side Story
rewatchability: 2h, pretty classic
review: Not bad. I liked Maria (Rachel Zegler) and Tony’s (Ansel Elgort) chemistry, but Tony’s chemistry was even better with Riff (Mike Faist). Really nice songs, especially “America”, and it’s also like totally ripped off of Romeo and Juliet. Like completely. Bernardo (David Alvarez) looks perfectly cast and acts really well, and Anita is really strong and captivating on screen. Overall really great to watch.

title: Wonder Woman 1984
rewatchability: 2h30, feels pretty long
review: Man, there was a LOT of stuff in this movie; it straight up tried to be Infinity War. The beginning was promising, if a little slower than I would have liked, and Barbara is a hilarious and relatable character from the get-go, whose motivations and actions are completely understandable. Diana (Gal Gadot) is quaint and charming as usual, and her introduction isn’t bad either. The movie has a real classic feeling to it, with bright colours and over-the-top action scenes - it reminds me of the original Superman movies. Anyway, Maxwell Lord (Pedro Pascal) is also a fair villain in terms of being compelling, even if his plan seems to be a little foggy. Steve Trevor (Chris Pine) also returns for a sweet, fish-out-of-water storyline and some good romantic scenes. The movie does seem a little bloated in that sense, and I think it tries to do way too much. There’s themes of strong vs weak, assault, greed, war, and it’s a period piece (the costumes are GREAT by the way). Most callbacks are great, and Patty Jenkins manages to avoid the sillier aspects of the comics, but as a movie, the story will likely tire you out by the end.
spoilerReview: First up, that post-credits scene was a banger - Linda Carter I was definitely not expecting, so kudos. Now, the story. The final scene left the potential for SO many plotholes (what if some people didn’t renounce their wish?). There were so many moving parts, what with the oil plot, Alastair being a thing, Diana and Steve, Diana randomly wanting to fly, Barbara, the “Truth vs Lies” motif that tried to justify the MacGuffin, and the giant metal suit (that for some reason didn’t get electrocuted?). Just confusing. The scene where the world is dying and Diana is flying is so strange as well. Also how does she talk to the whole world without a camera? It’s just confusing. Anyway, the part with her losing her powers and then giving up Steve to get them back and save everyone is cool. That should have been the main story. Also I kinda expected Max to die at the beginning when he wished to be a wish stone (doesn’t sound like a very responsible wish). And also the first scene was cute, but I don’t really know where it fits in.

title: Yesterday
intendedAudience: People who like the Beatles, people who don’t know the Beatles
rewatchability: About 2h00, but full of Beatles songs, so you could watch it every day
review: HEY JUDE. DON’T MAKE IT BAD. Man I love the Beatles. Just for having Beatles songs, this movie is like ultimately rewatchable. Ellie and Jack (Himesh Patel) had a really cute story, and it seemed really real. Ed Sheeran was great as himself, and the comedy in this movie was totally there. The scene with the three Beatles-rememberers geeking out over the songs; the yellow submarine, etc. hit soooo hard. Honestly what legends. And then obviously THE SCENE with THE LEGEND. Our man John Lennon (Robert Calysle) pulled up to complete Jack’s arc, and it was great. Then the last scene was wonderful, and I think that it was the only acceptable ending to this movie. Still the Let It Be scene was hilarious, and Deborah (Kate McKinnon) was pretty funny too. Overall it was really heart-warming, and I can only imagine how much nostalgia it must have caused for long-time Beatles fans.

title: Your Name
rewatchability: Bro I could watch this every day
review: My heart. Hurts. So much. Right now. You don’t understand. This movie brought out more emotions in me than my actual life did. I swear animation is just on another level - Studio Ghibli-esque. Apparently it’s the highest grossing anime movie ever, and it completely freaking deserves it. Since Mitsuha and Taki switch bodies and are joint protagonists, it’s only right to have them both win together. When you look up chemistry in the dictionary, pictures of these two come up. Straight up. Whoever wrote the plot needs a medal, too. Shit, I’ll give you the medal myself. The amount of TENSION is unheard of. But it’s also SO easy to watch - there’s comedy, there’s relatability, and the classic coming-of-age heart. The supporting characters are really well built-up also, never forgotten or misplaced. The animation itself is BREATHTAKING, the music is wonderful (very anime-like) and there’s just this wonderful childhood nuance that’s captured in the spirit of this movie that’s unheard of. This one’s for the ages.
spoilerReview: Bruh. I’ll admit it. That whole “the village was destroyed 3 years in the past” thing got me. I spent a solid 20 minutes being like “Bring her back to life. Now.” I really couldn’t deal with her being dead. And the scene where they finally meet on the edge of the crater… massive feels. The “I love you” on her hand was brilliant too. And of course at the end “What’s your name?” That was solid as can be, even if I really really wanted to see them actually remember who they were. Also damn how awesome were Mitsuha’s friends? Real MVPs just went along with her crazy vision - absolute goals. And Taki’s friends took him to the village? I swear they’re actually the best. Finally the kuchikamisake was the holy grail of the movie - that’s what made it all work, and you could really feel the love. Also the half-night stuff was great. I swear there’s just so many little things that make this movie amazing, but even if you just watch it to watch it, there’s hardly anything better. Masterclass. Broke my entire heart.

title: Zack Snyder’s Justice League
rewatchability: Once in a couple months, even though it’s 4h
review: Wow, so much better than the theatrical version. Steppenwolf (Ciaran Hinds) is an actual character with motivations and a face, and the wealth of riches of the DC universe isn’t squandered one bit. The story was well-paced (the “parts” made it a little episodic, but I guess that makes arranging a 4h movie easier) and all members of the Justice League were set up with defining characteristics and motivations that helped decide their actions later in the movie. Wonder Woman (Gal Gadot) was a mature leader, Batman (Ben Affleck) was a responsible protagonist, Aquaman (Jason Momoa) towed the line between uncaring and heroic very well, while Flash (Ezra Miller) was comedic and compelling at the same time. Cyborg was by far the most improved performer this time around, with his arc and relationship with his father (Joe Morton) basically acting as the framework for the movie. His backstory, abilities, and emotional journey was much better explained here. Darkseid (Ray Porter) and DaSaad (Peter Guiness) had just the right amount of ominous energy, with reverence from Steppenwolf, and the parademons didn’t have too much of the spotlight. The score was great (Wonder Woman’s Amazon theme was iconic) and the tone was a lot more streamlined.
spoilerReview: Okay. Lots here. The superman revival plot device was so much better set up with that conversation of the burned-down house, which was awesome. And Lex Luthor being shown in that opening scene was helpful too. The focus on Lois Lane (Amy Adams) paid off well, even if most of the superman scenes weren’t that great - I think the one thing I liked about the original better was superman’s role in the finale. That said, Martian Manhunter’s (Harry Lenix) role here was really quite interesting, in the same way that Nick Fury showed up in Iron Man. The dream sequence at the end was pure genius, and would have built up SO much hype for the sequel if we didn’t already know there wasn’t going to be one. Wonderful storytelling, and I’m glad that the Joker (Jared Leto) could redeem himself with this performance. As always, Alfred (Jeremy Irons) was perfect, Martha (Diane Lane) wasn’t bad, Vulko (Willem Dafoe) was a bit random, and Mera (Amber Heard) had a strange British accent here. Ryan Choi (Kai Zheng) was a nice easter egg, even if I was surprised they didn’t work in a Green Lantern somewhere. Either way, definitely a great showing. The Unity was an awesome idea, and the Anti-Life sounds like it would be a great arc in the future. Kudos to Snyder, and I’m glad we got to see his original vision.

title: Zombieland
rewatchability: It’s only 1h30, and pretty action-packed
review: So yeah, basically funny real-life Call of Duty zombies. Not a bad idea. Columbus is a pretty decent protagonist (Eisenberg is interesting and gives off Michael Cera vibes) and has a decent supporting cast of Emma Stone (who’s awesome here too), Woody Harrselson, and Abigail Breslin. All good. The action is definitely there, and Bill Hurray makes a cameo (which I don’t really get). It’s entertaining, for sure, in a basic popcorn flick kinda way.
